a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller published personal data without necessary legitimation under Article 6.1 GDPR, specifically publishing a photograph and personal data of the claimant without express consent or other valid legal basis.
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA sanctioned a real estate company for GDPR violations. The website lacked proper privacy policy referencing outdated legislation and published personal data without consent. The DPA issued a warning for Article 13 violation and €8,000 fine for Article 6.1 violation. Aggravating factors included negligent action and complaint-based discovery.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) was partially discussed. The DPA considered the intentional/negligent character (b) as aggravating and the manner of discovery (h) as aggravating. Other factors were not discussed in the decision.
authority_name_norm: Spanish Agency for Data Protection

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR for publishing a judicial sentence containing personal data on their website and Facebook. The DPA found this invalid as the legitimate interest did not prevail over the data subject's fundamental rights and freedoms, and the publication was not proportionate.
a75_case_summary: A sports club published a judicial sentence containing personal data of a former board member on its website and Facebook. The DPA found the publication violated Article 6(1) GDPR as the legitimate interest basis was invalid - the club's interest in informing members did not prevail over the data subject's rights. The publication was disproportionate and not limited to club members.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature, gravity and duration of the infringement as aggravating, noting the data remained accessible through search engines despite removal attempts. Intentionality/negligence was aggravating due to lack of diligence in data removal. Measures to mitigate damage were aggravating as adequate measures were not implemented.
authority_name_norm: Spanish Agency for Data Protection

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the controller violated data minimization principles by requiring excessive identification documents beyond what was necessary for the stated purposes of vacation rental service and compliance with Catalan police registration requirements.
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA sanctioned a UAE-based vacation rental company for GDPR violations. The company required excessive personal data including ID images beyond what was necessary for rental services and Catalan police registration requirements. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(c) (data minimization) and 13 (transparency obligations), imposing fines totaling €75,000.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of processing personal data as essential to the defendant's business activity as aggravating, and found intentionality/negligence in the infringement as the defendant was fully aware of its procedures. No mitigating factors were discussed.
authority_name_norm: Spanish Agency for Data Protection

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found Vodafone processed claimant's personal data without legitimacy as they lacked documentation proving contracting of prepaid lines, violating Article 6.1 GDPR.
a75_case_summary: Vodafone Spain processed claimant's personal data for two prepaid phone lines without proper documentation or legitimacy. The DPA found violation of Article 6.1 GDPR due to lack of lawful basis for processing. Vodafone paid a reduced fine of €56,000 through voluntary payment mechanism.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered intentionality/negligence (Art 83.2.b) and link between business activity and data processing (Art 83.2.k) as aggravating factors. Other factors were not discussed in detail.
authority_name_norm: Spanish Agency for Data Protection

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: AVILON CENTER 2016 S.L. made marketing calls to a data subject whose phone number was registered on the Robinson advertising exclusion list. The company claimed a software error momentarily blocked access to the Robinson list during the call. The Spanish DPA found a violation of the right to object under Article 21 GDPR and Article 48.1.b) of Spain's Telecommunications Law. The company paid a reduced fine of €12,000 through voluntary payment and recognition of responsibility.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Spanish Agency for Data Protection

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis; DPA found no legitimate basis under Article 6.1 GDPR; processing was done without consent or authorization.
a75_case_summary: Individual published audiovisual material from court proceedings on Twitter without consent; DPA found violation of Article 6.1 GDPR as no legal basis existed; Fine imposed considering aggravating factors including scope of dissemination and negligent action.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, technical measures; Mitigating: offender not linked to data processing activities; Other factors not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Spanish Agency for Data Protection

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed no legal basis; DPA found violation of Article 6(1) due to lack of consent mechanism; No valid consent obtained as users could send data without affirmative action
a75_case_summary: Individual website owner operated e-commerce site without proper consent mechanism, privacy policy, or cookie compliance; DPA found violations of GDPR Article 6(1) (consent), Article 13 (transparency), and LSSI Article 22.2 (cookies); Defendant paid reduced fine of €1,800 acknowledging responsibility.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Spanish Agency for Data Protection

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: GEOPOST delivery driver improperly posted notice with complainant's personal data on outside of mailbox, exposing name, surname, address and phone number to third parties. DPA found violations of Article 5(1)(f) confidentiality principle and Article 32 security measures. Company argued human error but DPA held controller responsible for employee actions and inadequate security measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration, negligent character, technical/organizational measures, categories of data affected. Mitigating: actions to mitigate damage, merger by absorption circumstance. Neutral: cooperation with authority.
authority_name_norm: Spanish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR to justify sharing individualized heating consumption data with all community members. The DPA found this legal basis invalid as the data sharing constituted a breach of confidentiality principles.
a75_case_summary: A housing community shared individualized heating consumption data (by floor/letter) with all owners via email before a meeting. The Spanish DPA found this violated Article 5(1)(f) GDPR (integrity and confidentiality) as personal data was unduly exposed. The controller claimed legitimate interest but this was rejected. A €600 fine was proposed but reduced to €480 through voluntary payment.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Spanish Data Protection Agency

a7_defendant_name: AXA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT MANAGERS IBERICA S.A.
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: AXA Real Estate sent encrypted USB with personal data via courier but included password in same envelope. USB was lost during transport. Spanish DPA found violation of Article 32 GDPR security obligations. Fine reduced from €100,000 to €80,000 due to voluntary payment.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; intentional/negligent character was aggravating; measures to mitigate damage were mitigating; technical measures were aggravating; previous infringements were mitigating; cooperation was mitigating; categories of data were aggravating; manner infringement became known was mitigating.
authority_name_norm: Spanish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Spanish DPA sanctioned INFINITY ECOM S.L. for GDPR Article 13 violations regarding inadequate privacy policy information and LSSI Article 22.2 violations regarding improper cookie usage. The website lacked proper identification of the data controller, information about data subject rights, and compliant cookie consent mechanisms. The DPA imposed two €5,000 fines and ordered corrective measures within one month.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and gravity of the infringement as aggravating, particularly the defendant's activity involving personal data processing. Intentionality was also considered aggravating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Spanish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent was requested but DPA found processing lacked legal basis under Article 6(1) GDPR as inclusion in WhatsApp groups without proper legitimization violated the principle of legality.
a75_case_summary: A former employee filed a complaint against VUKMAL TRADE for requiring use of personal mobile phones for work and including employees in WhatsApp groups without proper legal basis. The Spanish DPA found violation of Article 6(1) GDPR as processing lacked legitimization. The company paid a reduced fine of €1,200 and was ordered to bring processing into compliance within 6 months.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Spanish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: DIGI claimed processing was lawful under Article 6(1)(b) GDPR as necessary for contract execution. The AEPD found this legal basis invalid in this specific case because a third party impersonated the data subject and obtained a SIM duplicate, violating the principle of legality.
a75_case_summary: DIGI issued a duplicate SIM card to an impersonator who fraudulently obtained it from a distributor point of sale. The AEPD found DIGI violated Article 6(1) GDPR as the processing lacked a lawful basis when the duplicate was issued to a third party instead of the legitimate data subject. The AEPD rejected DIGI's arguments about prior phishing and imposed a €70,000 fine, citing inadequate diligence in identity verification procedures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The AEPD systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature/gravity/duration of infringement, negligent character, degree of responsibility, and link between business activity and data processing. Mitigating factor was actions taken to mitigate damage. The absence of previous infringements and lack of benefits obtained were considered neutral factors, not mitigating.
authority_name_norm: Spanish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent but the DPA found it invalid because consent was not freely given; the club required consent for image processing as a condition for registration of minors in sports activities, which vitiated consent from the beginning.
a75_case_summary: A sports club required parents to consent to image processing of their minor children as a condition for registration in sports activities. The Spanish DPA found this violated Article 7 GDPR as consent was not freely given. The club acknowledged responsibility and paid a reduced fine of €600. The DPA also ordered corrective measures to respect data protection rights of those refusing consent.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and gravity of the infringement as aggravating, the impact on minors' rights as aggravating, and the recognition of responsibility and voluntary payment as mitigating. Most Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Spanish Data Protection Agency

a2_authority_name: Autoritat Catalana de Protecció de Dades
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed public task legal basis under Article 6(1)(e). The DPA found this basis valid for video surveillance but invalid for biometric processing due to lack of specific legal authorization. The DPA concluded biometric processing lacked proper legal basis.
a75_case_summary: Barcelona City Council implemented facial recognition in public CCTV without proper legal basis. The DPA found biometric processing violated GDPR principles and lacked specific legal authorization. The system processed special category data without adequate safeguards. The DPA imposed corrective measures and a €240,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of infringement, negligent character, inadequate technical measures, and special category data. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and actions to mitigate damage. Other mitigating factors were considered.
authority_name_raw: Autoritat Catalana de Protecció de Dades
authority_name_norm: Autoritat Catalana de Protecció de Dades

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Eulen sent six emails to families/guardians of disabled care center users without using BCC, exposing email addresses and sometimes names/institutional affiliations. The DPA found violation of Article 5(1)(f) confidentiality principle due to lack of diligence by staff. The entity acknowledged responsibility and implemented measures to prevent recurrence.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included number of affected people and link between offender's activity and data processing. Mitigating factors included lack of intentionality, implemented security measures, non-special category data, and no profits obtained from infringement.
authority_name_norm: Catalan Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that none of the conditions from Article 6(1) were met for the processing, as the police officer processed personal data without a justified and legal reason related to the performance of his official duties.
a75_case_summary: A Slovenian police officer unlawfully accessed personal data of five individuals through the police information system without any legitimate purpose related to his official duties. The Information Commissioner found violations of Article 5(1)(a) and (b) and Article 6(1) GDPR as the processing lacked legal basis and was incompatible with specified purposes. A total fine of €500 was imposed for the five separate violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Information Commissioner

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Company redirected former employees' emails to responsible person without legal basis. DPA found unlawful processing of email addresses and traffic data under Article 8(1) GDPR. Fines imposed: €300 for responsible person, €6,255 for company.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Information Commissioner

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller processed personal data without consent and without another legal basis; the DPA found no valid legal basis for the processing; violation of Article 6 was established.
a75_case_summary: An owners' association displayed payment lists containing members' names on a notice board without consent or other legal basis; the DPA found violations of Article 6 (lawfulness) and Article 83(5)(a); a fine of 2,462.5 RON and warning were issued; corrective measures were ordered to ensure GDPR compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: National Supervisory Authority

a2_authority_name: National Supervisory Authority for the Processing of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Romanian DPA investigated Med Life SA following a complaint about denied access to CCTV footage. The DPA found violations of Articles 12(4) and 15(3) GDPR for failing to provide requested video recordings and omitting information about complaint rights. A fine of 9,839.6 lei was imposed and the company was ordered to comply with the data subject's access request.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_raw: National Supervisory Authority for the Processing of Personal Data
authority_name_norm: National Supervisory Authority for the Processing of Personal Data

a2_authority_name: National Supervisory Authority for the Processing of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: OTP Bank Romania SA was penalized for GDPR violations following a complaint-based investigation. The bank failed to implement sufficient security measures under Article 32, resulting in a security incident where personal data was sent to the wrong recipient via email. The bank also violated Article 33 by failing to notify the supervisory authority of the security incident. The DPA imposed a €3,000 fine for Article 32 violation and a warning for Article 33 violation, along with corrective measures ordering improved security protocols and incident response procedures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_raw: National Supervisory Authority for the Processing of Personal Data
authority_name_norm: National Supervisory Authority for the Processing of Personal Data

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Water Canal Ilfov SA was fined for GDPR security violations after a data breach notification. The breach occurred when email addresses were mistakenly placed in the "To" field instead of "BCC" when sending messages to users, resulting in unauthorized disclosure of personal data. The DPA found the operator failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure security corresponding to processing risk. The breach affected a significant number of individuals.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA found the nature/gravity of the infringement aggravating due to the security failure. The manner the infringement became known (through self-reporting) was mitigating. The lack of adequate technical/organizational measures was aggravating. Cooperation with the authority was mitigating.
authority_name_norm: National Supervisory Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Individual political party official disclosed personal data of 10 supporters on social media including names,signatures,nationality,dates of birth,addresses,ID numbers,and political choices;Romanian DPA found violation of Article 32 security obligations and Article 5(1)(f) integrity/confidentiality principle;Fine of RON 2,437 imposed with corrective order to delete data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: National Supervisory Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Romanian DPA sanctioned two financial operators for GDPR violations following ransomware attacks. Investigations revealed inadequate security measures under Article 32(1)(b)(c) and (2), leading to unauthorized access and loss of data integrity/availability. Fines were imposed considering remedial measures taken and Article 83 criteria.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, data categories as aggravating, but cooperation and mitigation actions as mitigating factors in sanction determination.
authority_name_norm: National Supervisory Authority

a2_authority_name: Autoritatea Națională de Supraveghere a Prelucrării Datelor cu Caracter Personal
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for marketing; DPA found no valid legitimate interest as controller failed to demonstrate balancing test; consent was invalid as not freely given due to contractual dependency.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 2/2019 on Article 6(1)(f); Guidelines 05/2020 on consent
a75_case_summary: ANSPDCP fined RCS & RDS €600,000 for GDPR violations in marketing communications; Controller sent unsolicited marketing without valid consent or legitimate interest; Violations included lack of transparency, invalid legal basis, and inadequate security measures; DPA found systematic failures in compliance with Articles 5, 6, 32, and 33.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of infringement, intentional character, inadequate security measures, and previous infringements; Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and measures to mitigate damage; The fine was calculated based on turnover and seriousness of violations.
authority_name_raw: Autoritatea Națională de Supraveghere a Prelucrării Datelor cu Caracter Personal
authority_name_norm: Autoritatea Națională de Supraveghere a Prelucrării Datelor cu Caracter Personal

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: BRISTOL LOGISTICS SA was fined for GDPR violations after a security breach involving theft of personnel files containing employee data. The company failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure security corresponding to processing risks. The DPA ordered corrective measures including reviewing security procedures and conducting data protection training.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: National Supervisory Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for telemarketing; the DPA found this invalid as marketing requires consent under Italian law (Article 130 of the Code); the DPA stated legitimate interest conditions were not documented or properly assessed.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of data controller and data processor under the GDPR;Guidelines 1/2024 on processing of personal data based on Article 6(1)(f)
a75_case_summary: Energia Verde was found to have unlawfully processed personal data for telemarketing via third parties without proper controller-processor agreements. Violations included non-cooperation with the DPA, lack of legal basis for marketing calls (invalid legitimate interest claim), inadequate responses to data subject rights requests, and insufficient transparency. The DPA imposed corrective measures and a €100,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of violations, negligence, lack of cooperation, and categories of data affected. Mitigating factors included corrective measures implemented during proceedings. The fine was set at 0.5% of the maximum.
authority_name_norm: Italian Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing for scientific research purposes. The DPA found the purpose definition lawful but transparency inadequate regarding specific pathology and retention periods.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation (EU) 2016/679;Opinion 03/2013 on purpose limitation;Guidelines on transparency pursuant to Regulation 2016/679;Opinion 28/2024 on certain data protection aspects related to the processing of personal data in the context of AI models
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found violations in Menarini Silicon Biosystems' processing of health data for AI tool development. The company processed pseudonymized health data from cancer patients to train its CellFind algorithm for multiple myeloma detection. The DPA confirmed breaches of transparency, storage limitation, and accountability principles, but dismissed the purpose limitation challenge after company clarifications.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature of health data and processing context. Mitigating factors included lack of intent, cooperation with authorities, absence of material harm from storage violations, and innovative technology context. The fine was reduced to €21,000 considering these factors.
authority_name_norm: Italian Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 9/2022 on the Notification of Personal Data Breach under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Poste Vita S.p.A. disclosed personal data relating to life insurance policies to an unauthorized third party who impersonated the data subject via email requests containing forged signatures and detailed policy information. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (f) for failing to verify the requester's identity and Article 33 for delayed breach notification. The company argued it was deceived by sophisticated fraud but was found negligent in its verification procedures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the significant nature of violations affecting general principles and negligent conduct. Mitigating factors included immediate investigation initiation, cooperation with authorities, absence of precedents, and implementation of corrective measures. The financial situation was considered but not detailed.
authority_name_norm: Italian Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: UCD was investigated for 7 personal data breaches involving unauthorized access to email accounts and credentials posted online. The DPC found infringements of Articles 5(1)(f), 32(1) for inadequate security measures, Article 5(1)(e) for excessive data retention, and Article 33(1) for delayed breach notification. Corrective measures included a €70,000 fine, compliance order, and reprimand.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Commission

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Tusla breached GDPR by failing to implement appropriate security measures when sharing documents with third parties, resulting in three data breaches where sensitive information about children in care was disclosed. The DPC found infringements of Articles 32(1) and 33(1) GDPR. A €75,000 fine was imposed along with orders to bring processing into compliance and reprimands.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Commission

a7_defendant_name: City of Dublin Education and Training Board
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: DPC investigated CDETB's personal data breach involving student grant applicants' data including special categories. Found security failures, delayed breach notification to DPC, and failure to notify data subjects despite DPC direction. Imposed €125,000 fine and compliance order.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPC considered security failures and delayed notification as aggravating. Mitigating factors included CDETB's cooperation, acceptance of findings, apology, and proactive security improvements. Final fine reduced from proposed €210,000 due to mitigation.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Commission

a36_legal_basis_summary: DPC found DSP failed to identify valid lawful basis for biometric data collection under Article 6(1) and special category processing under Article 9(1) for SAFE 2 registration
a75_case_summary: DPC investigated DSP's use of facial matching technology for Public Services Card registration (SAFE 2). Found DSP lacked valid lawful basis for biometric data collection and retention under Articles 5(1)(a), 6(1), 9(1) and 5(1)(e). Also violated transparency obligations under Articles 13(1)(c) and 13(2)(a) and DPIA requirements under Article 35(7)(b) and (c). DPC issued reprimand, €550,000 fine, and order to cease biometric processing within 9 months if no lawful basis established.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPC discussed nature/gravity as aggravating due to scale and sensitivity of biometric data processing affecting 70% of population. Technical measures were found adequate and neutral. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Commission

a36_legal_basis_summary: DPA found no lawful basis for processing sensitive personal data obtained through broad scoping questions; processing was excessive and disproportionate for litigation purposes despite potential legal basis provisions under national law.
a75_case_summary: DPC investigated Department of Health's processing of personal data in 29 litigation files involving special educational needs cases. Found infringements: processing sensitive personal data obtained through broad scoping questions was excessive and disproportionate; privacy notice lacked details of information sharing practices; inadequate security measures. Fine imposed and ban on processing sensitive data for settlement purposes.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPC considered GDPR factors but did not systematically discuss Article 83(2). Nature/gravity of infringement, categories of personal data affected, and technical/organizational measures were aggravating factors in sanction determination.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Commission

a7_defendant_name: A&G Couriers Limited T/A Fastway Couriers (Ireland)
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The DPC conducted an inquiry into A&G Couriers Limited following an audit which revealed multiple GDPR violations. The company failed to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure data protection principles. Violations included inadequate data retention policies, excessive data collection, and insufficient security measures. The DPC found breaches across all Article 5 principles and issued corrective orders.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPC systematically applied Article 83(2) factors in determining the administrative fine. The nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, technical measures, and categories of data affected were aggravating factors. Cooperation with the authority and actions to mitigate damage were mitigating factors. Other mitigating circumstances were also considered.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Commission

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: DPC fined Meta €251M for GDPR violations related to 2018 Facebook breach affecting 29M accounts. Violations included inadequate breach notification documentation and failure to implement data protection by design/default. The breach exposed sensitive personal data including religious beliefs and children's data through exploitation of user token vulnerabilities.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPC considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to serious risks to fundamental rights; technical measures as aggravating due to design failures; and actions to mitigate damage as mitigating since breach was remedied quickly. Other factors not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Irish Data Protection Commission

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: DPC fined Meta €17m for failing to demonstrate security measures implemented for EU user data protection in context of 12 data breaches between June-December 2018; Found violations of Articles 5(2) and 24(1) GDPR; Cross-border processing required Article 60 co-decision process with all EU supervisory authorities; Consensus achieved despite objections from two authorities.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Commission

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: TikTok infringed GDPR regarding transfers of EEA user data to China and transparency requirements; Failed to verify Chinese law provides essentially equivalent protection; Ordered to bring processing into compliance within 6 months with suspension of transfers if not compliant.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Irish Data Protection Commission

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for significant public interest under Icelandic education laws. DPA found authorization valid under Article 11(7) of Act no. 90/2018 but security measures were inadequate.
a75_case_summary: A teacher at Breiðholt Multicultural School mistakenly emailed sensitive student information to unauthorized recipients. The DPA found inadequate security measures violated integrity/confidentiality requirements. The school took prompt remedial actions but lacked proper organizational measures to prevent such errors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature of sensitive data was aggravating, while negligence (not intent), mitigation measures, cooperation, and first-time offense were mitigating. The violation was not long-term but involved significant privacy reduction.
authority_name_norm: Privacy Policy Board

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for healthcare purposes under Icelandic law. The DPA found violations of security and integrity principles but did not invalidate the legal basis itself.
a75_case_summary: A healthcare institution improperly transferred sensitive patient data to a former employee during retirement procedures. The DPA found violations of security, integrity and confidentiality principles under Articles 5(1)(f), 24, 25 and 32 GDPR. Despite mitigation efforts, a fine of 3 million ISK was imposed due to the sensitive nature of the data and scope of the breach.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature of sensitive data and inadequate security measures. Mitigating factors included prompt breach notification, cooperation with authorities, lack of previous violations, and remedial actions taken.
authority_name_norm: Privacy Policy Board

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines of the European Privacy Council no. 7/2020 on the concepts responsible party and processor
a75_case_summary: InfoMentor ehf., processor of Mentor educational system, failed to implement adequate security measures resulting in unauthorized access to 424 children's ID numbers and photos. The DPA found breaches of Article 32 regarding security measures and Article 5(1)(f) integrity/confidentiality. A €3.5 million ISK fine was imposed due to the nature of children's data and company's responsibility as educational system processor.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, negligent character, technical measures deficiencies, and categories of personal data (children's data). Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority, manner infringement became known, and measures taken to prevent future breaches.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: Harpa Music and Conference Center ohf.
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary to fulfill contract under Article 6(1)(b). DPA found collection of ID numbers and birth dates was not necessary for ticket delivery as contract could be fulfilled using other identifying information.
a75_case_summary: Harpa collected ID numbers and birth dates for ticket purchases without proper legal basis. DPA found this violated data minimization and contract necessity principles under Article 6(1)(b). Processing was not necessary for ticket delivery as other identification methods were available. Fine imposed due to widespread practice and duration of violation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/duration was aggravating as violation affected many individuals over time. Negligence was mitigating as company acted in good faith. Cooperation was aggravating due to delayed responses. Special category data was aggravating as ID numbers have special protection.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: Office of the National Medical Examiner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found violations of security principles (Art 5(1)(f)) and specific security measures (Art 32) rather than invalidating any claimed legal basis for processing. The controller's role in health data processing was established but legal basis validity was not explicitly assessed.
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA fined the Office of the National Medical Examiner ISK 12,000,000 for security weaknesses in the Heilsuvera health portal that allowed unauthorized access to patient data. Two vulnerabilities existed: message section access through parameter manipulation (2015-2020) and maternity care attachment access through URL modification (2019-2020). The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 25, and 32 due to inadequate security measures for sensitive health data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of breach, negligent character, responsibility for technical measures, and categories of sensitive data. Mitigating factors included actions to reduce damage and voluntary breach reporting. The public service role of the defendant was considered as another mitigating factor.
authority_name_norm: Personal Protection

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f). The DPA found this basis invalid because the processing was not lawful, fair, or transparent, and the controller failed to demonstrate that legitimate interests outweighed data subjects' rights.
a75_case_summary: Creditinfo Lánstraust hf., a financial information agency, registered loan default information from eCommerce 2020 ApS without verifying that registration conditions were met. The DPA found violations of GDPR principles (lawfulness, fairness, transparency, and accountability) because the agency failed to check loan terms for proper authorization clauses and minimum amount requirements. The fine was based on the processing's onerous nature, profit motive, core business relevance, and delayed corrective actions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature/gravity/duration of the breach, negligence, inadequate technical measures, categories of data affected, and profit motive. Mitigating factors included cooperation with the DPA and actions to reduce damage. The fine amount was set at 2.5% of annual turnover considering these factors.
authority_name_norm: Personal Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found this invalid because the processing lacked transparency and proper authorization for credit reporting registration.
a75_case_summary: eCommerce 2020 ApS sent information about loan defaults to Creditinfo Lánstrausti hf. without proper authorization in loan terms and below minimum amount thresholds. The DPA found violations of GDPR principles including lawfulness, fairness, transparency and invalid legitimate interests basis. The fine was set at ISK 7.5 million considering the burdensome nature of credit reporting and the company's financial situation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, technical/organizational measures as aggravating, categories of personal data as aggravating, and profit motive as aggravating. Actions to mitigate damage were considered mitigating. The company's financial decline was also considered in fine determination.
authority_name_norm: Personal Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public interest in healthcare safety; DPA found violations as ministerial permission and DPA confirmation required by national law were not obtained for most agreements.
a75_case_summary: The Icelandic DPA conducted an ex officio investigation into the Capital Region Health Service's joint medical record system. The health service failed to obtain required ministerial permission and DPA confirmation for merging systems with 11 parties, violating data protection laws. Processing involved health data of approximately 195,000 individuals over several years. The DPA imposed a 5 million ISK fine considering the serious nature, duration, and sensitivity of data, while acknowledging remedial actions taken.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration and sensitive data were aggravating; cooperation and mitigation actions were mitigating; intentional character was aggravating. Other factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest based on freedom of expression and public interest; DPA found no valid legal basis as processing was not necessary or proportionate, and controller was not a press entity where such exceptions apply.
a75_case_summary: Municipal deputy mayor published photo of complainant and his minor child on Facebook during election campaign without consent, claiming legitimate interest in freedom of expression. DPA found no valid legal basis, violation of data protection principles (lawfulness, purpose limitation, minimization), and failure to respond to data subject rights requests. Ordered deletion and imposed fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating (serious infringement affecting privacy), intentional character as aggravating, and previous infringements as mitigating (first violation). Other factors were reviewed but not considered relevant.
authority_name_raw: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for performance of public tasks under Article 6(1)(e). The DPA found this valid for work-related data but invalid for private emails, requiring separate handling.
a75_case_summary: A former employee requested access to his 2018 workplace email archive after termination. The university denied access entirely. The DPA found the university breached Article 15 by refusing access to private emails and Article 12 by failing to provide transparent information. The DPA ordered access to private emails and imposed a HUF 200,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, actions to mitigate damage as aggravating, technical measures as aggravating, previous infringements as mitigating, and other factors as aggravating. The fine was set near the minimum considering mitigating circumstances.
authority_name_raw: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25 Data Protection by Design and by Default
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found ROBINSON-TOURS violated GDPR Articles 25(1)-(2), 32(1)(b), and 34(1) due to a website vulnerability that exposed personal data of 781 travelers including children. The data was accessible via Google search without authentication from November 2019 to February 2020. The DPA ordered a €20M HUF fine and mandated notification to data subjects.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included high-risk data nature, systemic security failures, and external discovery. Mitigating factors included lack of intentionality and no prior infringements. Cooperation and prompt reporting were noted but not explicitly mitigating.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest for data transfer to facilitate SZÉP Card applications; DPA found legitimate interest invalid as it served data subjects' interests, not controller's; Consent was also invalid due to power imbalance in employment relationship.
a75_case_summary: The case involved an employee complaint about inaccurate temporary address data retention and unauthorized data transfer to a financial institution. The DPA found violations of accuracy principle (Article 5(1)(d)), right to rectification/erasure (Articles 16-17), transparency obligations (Article 13), and invalid legal basis for data transfer (Article 6). The controller failed to properly respond to data subject requests and transferred personal data without adequate legal basis or information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered several mitigating factors: no harm to data subjects, first-time infringement, deletion of data after procedure initiation, single data subject affected, and transfer intended to benefit employees. Other Article 83(2) factors were not considered relevant. A fine was imposed as warning was deemed insufficient.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis. The DPA found consent invalid due to lack of voluntary, specific, informed and unambiguous expression. Consent was not properly separated for different processing purposes.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 05/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679;WP259 on consent
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found that a politician collected signatures for a political initiative without valid consent. The controller processed political opinion data (special category) without explicit consent and failed to provide adequate information. The DPA ordered deletion of all collected data and imposed a 1 million HUF fine for violations of Articles 5,6,9 and 13.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered special category data and duration as aggravating factors. It considered the breach negligible in nature and first-time offense as mitigating factors. Non-compliance with prior orders was also aggravating.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis was needed as they didn't process applicant's personal data; DPA found they processed telephone number without legal basis and violated Article 6(1) by failing to prove consent.
a75_case_summary: Debt collection agency recorded applicant's telephone number as client contact data without proper identification; DPA found violations of accuracy principle (Article 5(1)(d)) and lack of legal basis (Article 6(1)); fine imposed considering moderate seriousness, negligent conduct, and mitigating deletion before proceedings.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors discussed: nature/gravity was aggravating (moderately serious), intentional/negligent character was aggravating, actions to mitigate damage were mitigating (deleted data), previous infringements were mitigating (no prior convictions); other factors not discussed.
authority_name_raw: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for CCTV monitoring. The DPA accepted this legal basis as appropriate for workplace camera systems for property protection purposes but found specific violations regarding implementation.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a private company violated GDPR principles by installing CCTV cameras that monitored both property protection areas and employee workstations. The camera angle in one room allowed unreasonable monitoring of workers, violating purpose limitation and data minimization principles. Additionally, the company failed to provide adequate information about the CCTV system to employees for several months after implementation began.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including previous infringements as aggravating, cooperation as neutral, and limited scope of affected persons as mitigating. The fine was set considering the company's large size and the duration of infringements.
authority_name_raw: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Hungarian DPA found Google Ireland Ltd violated Articles 12(3) and 15(1) GDPR by failing to provide adequate information on processing of applicant's personal data in Google AdWords within required timeframe. The case involved cross-border processing with Hungarian DPA acting as lead authority after coordination with Irish DPA. Google eventually provided the information during proceedings, making compliance orders unnecessary. A fine of HUF 10,000 was imposed for procedural delays.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for property protection, but the DPA found this invalid as no balancing of interests test was presented and camera surveillance was disproportionate for asset protection purposes.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a solarium company violated GDPR by operating CCTV surveillance without valid legal basis and inadequate transparency. The company claimed legitimate interest for property protection but failed to provide required balancing test. Camera angles monitored excessive areas including tanning machines and public space without masking.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered delayed/incomplete responses aggravating, while cessation of operations was mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion was conducted.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(b) for subscriber data processing and Article 6(1)(a) for newsletter data. The DPA did not assess validity of legal bases but focused on storage limitation and security principles.
a75_case_summary: Digi telecom company stored customer data in test database for 1.5 years after error correction, violating storage limitation principle. A hacker exploited a 9-year-known vulnerability in unpatched CMS to access unencrypted data affecting 322,000+ individuals. DPA found breaches of Articles 5(1)(e) and 32(1)-(2) regarding storage limitation and security measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration of infringement, intentional/negligent character, categories of data affected, large number of data subjects. Mitigating: no previous infringements. Neutral: actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority.
authority_name_raw: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a7_defendant_name: Cooperative Communities Association for the Living World
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) and Article 9(2)(a) for special category data processing. The DPA found consent invalid due to inadequate information provision, lack of explicit consent for political contact purposes, and failure to implement two-step verification as described in privacy notice.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent;WP29 Guidelines WP259 on consent
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found two joint controllers violated GDPR in a political signature collection campaign. The controllers collected personal data without valid legal basis, provided inadequate information about processing purposes, and failed to demonstrate accountability. The DPA ordered data deletion, issued reprimands, and imposed 3 million HUF fines on each controller for processing special category data without proper consent and transparency.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: serious nature affecting many data subjects, multiple violations, long duration, negligent conduct, special category data, and lack of cooperation. Mitigating factor for one controller was being a natural person. The fine was imposed considering both specific and general deterrence objectives.
authority_name_raw: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) but DPA found consent invalid as it was not voluntary or demonstrated by unambiguous affirmative action; no other legal basis established for processing
a75_case_summary: Telecommunications provider failed to delete complainant's personal data from online directory despite multiple requests; DPA found invalid consent basis for processing and violations of erasure right, transparency obligations, and accountability principle; technical and administrative errors cited but controller responsibility upheld
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration, negligence, previous infringements, categories of data; Mitigating: cooperation, compensation offered, deletion during proceedings; Neutral: not applicable factors
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a7_defendant_name: Budapest Capital XVIII. district with the Pestszentlőrinc - Pestszentimre Municipality
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(e) for name/address data and Article 6(1)(a) for contact/health data. The DPA found the legal bases invalid due to lack of adequate information, specific purposes, and necessity/proportionality requirements.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a municipality violated GDPR by sending vaccine questionnaires without adequate information, processing contact data without specific purpose/valid consent, and unnecessarily processing health data. The DPA ordered compliance measures and imposed a 3M HUF fine. Violations included Articles 5(1)(b)(c), 6(1), 7(2), 9(1), 12(1), 13, and 14.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity, public authority role, lack of information, health data involved, multiple complaints. Mitigating: negligent not intentional, partial remediation, no previous infringements, financial situation. Neutral: cooperation.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller lacked any valid legal basis under Article 6(1) for processing the applicant's email address, as the data was provided erroneously by a third party without proper verification.
a75_case_summary: Magyar Telekom processed an email address erroneously provided by a third party customer and failed to delete it despite repeated requests from the actual data subject. The DPA found violations of accuracy principles, transparency obligations, and erasure rights, noting this was part of a recurring pattern of similar infringements. The company's organizational measures were inadequate as they required unnecessary administrative barriers like account login for non-customers to exercise data subject rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included persistent internal procedural problems, previous similar infringements, and the company's large size. Mitigating factors included the unintentional nature of the breach, deletion after Authority intervention, and that only contact data (not sensitive) was affected. The fine was set at 0.04% of annual turnover considering both aggravating and mitigating circumstances.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found consent invalid in employment context and required legitimate interest balancing test instead
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a car repair company violated GDPR by using CCTV cameras that monitored employees excessively in office-waiting and kitchen areas. The company improperly relied on employee consent instead of legitimate interest, failed to conduct balancing test, and provided inadequate information to employees. The DPA ordered camera angle adjustments, policy revisions, and imposed a HUF 500,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered aggravating factors including duration of infringement and notification via complaint after prior warnings. Mitigating factors included small number of affected persons, limited scope to two cameras, no specific harm, negligence rather than intent, and first-time violation. Cooperation was noted but not explicitly mitigating.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed both consent and legitimate interest as legal bases for marketing data processing. The DPA found consent invalid due to inadequate information and lack of proof, and legitimate interest invalid due to lack of proper balancing test and documentation.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency facilitating the application and interpretation of GDPR (WP259)
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a hotel company violated GDPR by processing personal data for marketing without valid legal basis. The controller failed to prove consent or legitimate interest, provided unclear information, and did not properly respond to data subject requests for deletion and access. Violations included Articles 5(2), 6(1), 7(1), 12(1)-(4), 15(1), and 17(1).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included long duration of violation and lack of cooperation. Mitigating factors included no previous infringements and procedural delays by the authority. The fine was set at HUF 500,000 considering both specific and general preventive purposes.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 9(2)(d) as legal basis for processing political opinion data. The DPA did not explicitly validate or invalidate this legal basis but focused on security violations.
a75_case_summary: Hungarian DPA found political party violated GDPR Articles 32(1)(a-b) and 32(2) by storing party sympathizer data in Google Sheets with inadequate security measures, allowing unauthorized public access. Also violated Article 5(2) by failing to demonstrate compliance measures to authority. Fine of 3,000,000 HUF imposed considering aggravating factors including special category data involvement and lack of cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: large number of data subjects, special category data, systemic security problem, lack of cooperation. Mitigating: no specific harm to data subjects, no previous infringements. Neutral: manner infringement became known.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a7_defendant_name: Deichmann Shoe Trade Limited Liability Company
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the company violated GDPR principles by failing to properly handle data subject requests for access and restriction of camera recordings, without establishing valid legal bases for processing.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA fined Deichmann for GDPR violations related to CCTV operations. The company failed to properly handle a data subject's requests for access to camera recordings and restriction of processing. The DPA found inadequate organizational measures and restrictive internal regulations that violated data subject rights under Articles 12, 15, 18, and 25.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included serious negligence, nature/gravity of infringement, and inadequate technical measures. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and actions to mitigate damage. Neutral factors included categories of personal data affected.
authority_name_raw: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(b) as legal basis for processing pregnancy data; the DPA found this valid only for verifying the 12th week of pregnancy and expected delivery date, but invalid for all other health data copied from pregnancy books which lacked proper legal basis under Article 6 or Article 9.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a financial institution violated GDPR by excessively copying pregnancy books containing health data beyond what was necessary to verify loan eligibility conditions. The controller lacked proper legal basis for processing extensive health data and failed to provide transparent information about data processing related to baby waiting loans.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included serious nature of infringements affecting many data subjects and sensitive health data processing. Mitigating factors included remedial actions taken, cooperation with authority, first-time offense, and uncertain legal situation created by government decree.
authority_name_raw: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) as legal basis for direct marketing. The DPA found consent invalid due to inadequate prior information, insufficient specificity of purposes, and lack of separate consent options for different marketing channels.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found Éremkibocsátó Kft. violated GDPR by processing personal data for direct marketing without adequate prior information and valid consent. The company failed to provide specific purpose definitions, separate consent options for different marketing channels, and transparent information about data transfers to processors. The DPA ordered compliance measures and imposed a 30 million HUF fine based on the serious nature of violations affecting potentially hundreds of thousands of data subjects.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: serious nature affecting many data subjects, gross negligence, insufficient technical measures, and profit-seeking motive. Mitigating factors were: no direct financial damage to data subjects and non-sensitive data. Neutral factors included: no mitigation measures taken, previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and manner of detection.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for debt collection purposes. DPA found this invalid as the legitimate interest did not outweigh data subject's rights since the claim was unenforceable against heirs under civil law. DPA found legal obligation under Article 6(1)(c) valid for retention of transfer order documents.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 Opinion 1/2010 on the concepts of "controller" and "processor";EDPB Guidelines 2/2019 on the processing of personal data under Article 6(1)(b) GDPR in the context of the provision of online services to data subjects
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a debt collection company violated multiple GDPR provisions in processing a claim against an heir. The company unlawfully processed personal data for debt collection purposes from May 25, 2018, to August 21, 2021, using an invalid legitimate interest basis since the claim was unenforceable against heirs under civil law. The DPA imposed a HUF 10 million fine citing aggravating factors including long duration, intentional negligence, lack of cooperation, and previous infringements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included: serious nature of multiple principle violations, significant impact on data subject's mourning process, long duration (3+ years), intentional/negligent character, lack of cooperation with authority, and previous infringements. No mitigating factors were mentioned.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest basis under Article 6(1)(f) for audio recordings during installation work. DPA found no legitimate interest assessment was performed and data processing was unnecessary and disproportionate, violating Article 6(1).
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a private installation company violated GDPR by making audio recordings during installation work without proper legal basis. The company claimed legitimate interest but failed to conduct an interest assessment and the processing was deemed unnecessary and disproportionate. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(b), 5(1)(c), 5(2), 6(1), and 13(1)-(2).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating circumstances included multiple violations and gross negligence. Mitigating circumstances included cooperation with authorities, termination of the practice, no previous violations, and administrative delay. The fine was set at HUF 300,000 considering the company's HUF 130 million turnover.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for customer satisfaction surveys. The DPA found this invalid due to lack of adequate information, lack of proper relationship between data subject and controller, and failure to demonstrate necessity of data processing for the stated purpose.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found an automotive importer violated GDPR by processing customer data for satisfaction surveys without adequate information and invalid legal basis. The importer used legitimate interest but failed to demonstrate proper relationship with data subjects or necessity of collected data. The DPA imposed a 5 million HUF fine and ordered compliance within 30 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration of infringement, lack of technical measures, market position. Mitigating: negligent character, no previous infringements, data categories not sensitive. Neutral: cooperation with authority, actions to mitigate damage.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for all processing. The DPA found consent invalid due to inadequate information, lack of transparency, and non-compliance with GDPR requirements for valid consent.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent;EDPB Guidelines 2/2019 on processing under Article 6(1)(b)
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found TV2 Media Group violated GDPR Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(b), 6(1), 12(1) and 13 regarding cookie consent practices on their websites. The consent framework was non-transparent, used misleading terminology, lacked adequate information, and had parallel consent systems. The DPA ordered compliance within 30 days and imposed a 10 million HUF fine considering the intentional nature, scale affecting millions, and lack of previous violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: nature/gravity/duration affecting millions, intentional character for profit, categories of personal data involved profiling. Mitigating factors included: no previous infringements, ongoing industry transition context. The cooperation was assessed as neutral.
authority_name_raw: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a7_defendant_name: ALDI HUNGARY FOOD Food Trade Deposit Company
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal obligation under consumer protection law for age verification, but the DPA found this legal basis invalid as the obligation was applied excessively beyond the "in case of doubt" requirement and violated data minimization principles.
a75_case_summary: ALDI Hungary implemented age verification practices for alcohol purchases that violated GDPR principles. The DPA found violations of transparency, data minimization, legal basis, information obligations, and data security requirements. The court annulled part of the original decision regarding log file storage but upheld other violations, leading to a reduced fine of HUF 80 million.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating circumstances included nature/gravity of violations, number of affected data subjects, national scope of violations, and manner of discovery. Mitigating circumstances included narrow categories of data affected and consumer protection purpose. Neutral circumstances included cooperation, remedial measures, and previous infringements.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for journalistic purposes. DPA found the balancing of interests was inadequately performed, focusing only on controller's interests without considering data subject's rights, making the legal basis invalid.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a media company violated GDPR by publishing articles about a midwife's professional activities without proper legal basis. The articles contained personal data including name, role in criminal proceedings, qualifications, and image. The DPA found breaches of Articles 5(1)(a),(b),(c), 5(2), 6(1), 14(2), 15(1),(3), 17(1),(3), and 21(1). A fine of HUF 10 million was imposed along with deletion and restriction orders.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration and intentional character were aggravating; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; previous infringements were aggravating; categories of personal data affected were aggravating.
authority_name_raw: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: National Authority for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a7_defendant_name: AMPLIFON Magyarország Kereskedelmi és Szolgáltató Llátolt Anelösségő Társaság
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found consent invalid as being included in public register does not constitute clear affirmative action; no valid legal basis was established.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found Amplifon violated GDPR by processing name/address data from national address register for direct marketing disguised as market research. The company sent postal invitations for hearing screenings to 300,000-400,000 elderly individuals without valid legal basis (consent invalid) and inadequate information. Violations included unfair processing, purpose limitation, and transparency obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: serious nature of violations, large number of data subjects (elderly vulnerable group), negligent behavior, previous infringement. Mitigating: no prior GDPR violation, took remedial actions after inspection. Neutral: cooperation with authority, manner of detection.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing based on Article 6(1)(e) public task. The DPA found this legal basis valid for the vaccination registration processing but did not assess its validity for the rights response failures.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found the National Health Insurance Fund Manager violated GDPR by failing to respond to data subject requests within statutory deadlines and lacking transparent procedures for identification. The controller hindered rights exercise by requiring formal identification methods not communicated in advance. The DPA imposed a HUF 500,000 fine considering the seriousness and lack of cooperation as aggravating factors, while acknowledging pandemic challenges as mitigating.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors but not systematically. Aggravating factors included violation seriousness and lack of cooperation. Mitigating factors included pandemic challenges and no prior infringements. The nature/gravity was aggravating, previous infringements were mitigating, and cooperation was aggravating.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a2_authority_name: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for EDM emails but the DPA found it invalid due to inadequate information provision and inseparable connection between service subscription and marketing consent, violating Article 7(4) GDPR.
a75_case_summary: The Hungarian DPA found a media company violated GDPR by automatically enrolling service subscribers into marketing emails without valid consent. The consent was invalid due to inadequate information about data processing duration and inseparable connection between service terms and marketing consent. The DPA imposed a HUF 2 million fine and ordered compliance measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered duration as aggravating, negligence as mitigating, cooperation and remediation as mitigating, no prior infringements as mitigating, and only email data affected as mitigating. Other factors were not discussed.
authority_name_raw: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority
authority_name_norm: National Data Protection and Freedom of Information Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A toll management company operating CCTV for toll violation detection failed to properly respond to a data subject's access request. The company initially claimed it could only provide information with prosecutor order and DPA permission. After DPA intervention, the company provided available data but without visual material. The DPA imposed a €1,000 fine for delayed satisfaction of access rights, noting it had informed the company in 2017 about such obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/duration as aggravating due to delayed response and previous infringements as aggravating due to 2017 notification about access rights obligations. Other Art 83(2) factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Hellenic DPA imposed a €5,000 fine on Municipality of Athens for failing to respond to an EDPS questionnaire regarding DPO definition and position. The audit was part of a wider EDPS initiative examining DPO roles in public bodies. The penalty was issued under GDPR and national law 4624/2019 for non-cooperation with supervisory authority.
