a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed delays were due to teleworking arrangements and increased fraud cases; DPA found these insufficient to justify GDPR violations and noted failure to implement proper procedures.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines;WP29 Guidelines on transparency (WP260 rev.01);Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines (WP253)
a75_case_summary: National Bank of Greece violated GDPR access rights in multiple fraud-related cases with delays up to 7 months. The DPA found systemic failures in procedures despite existing policies, noting the bank used personal data in litigation before providing it to data subjects. Fines were imposed for both specific violations and general non-compliance with accountability principles.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, previous infringements, and technical/organizational measures. No mitigating factors were identified; cooperation and other factors were considered neutral.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: PPC S.A. failed to respond to a data subject's access request within the required timeframe. The Authority found violations of Article 12(3) and (4) GDPR regarding timely response obligations. The fine was imposed due to the repeated nature of this infringement, referencing a previous similar violation in Decision 15/2019.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The Authority considered the repeated nature of the infringement as aggravating under Article 83(2). No other factors were systematically discussed in the decision.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: Ministry of Rural Development and Food
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Hellenic DPA conducted an audit of DPO appointments in public bodies as part of an EDPS initiative. The Ministry of Rural Development and Food failed to appoint a DPO for a period and did not respond timely to the Authority's questionnaire. The Authority imposed administrative sanctions under GDPR and national law for these violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Opinion 8/2019 on the competence of the supervisory authority in the event of change of circumstances concerning the main or single establishment
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA found a golf course company violated Law 2472/1997 by failing to respond to a data subject's access request regarding CCTV footage. The controller claimed the recording system was non-functional but failed to provide evidence. The DPA noted lack of compliance with notification requirements and difficult cooperation with authorities.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to delayed response and lack of cooperation. The intentional/negligent character was aggravating as the controller failed to respond properly. Cooperation with supervisory authority was aggravating due to difficult cooperation.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: Standard Centre for Speech and Special Needs Education — DIMITRA
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the controller violated Article 15 by refusing access to a parent exercising parental responsibility, noting that parental custody holders are legal representatives entitled to access minor child data unless a court decision provides otherwise.
a75_case_summary: The Hellenic DPA found an education center violated GDPR by refusing a father's access request for his minor child's therapy session data and tax documents. The center incorrectly claimed it needed mother's consent despite father having parental responsibility. The DPA ordered compliance with the access request and imposed €8,000 in fines for both the access violation and non-compliance with the DPA's previous mandate.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: COSMOTE experienced a personal data breach involving subscriber call data leakage from September 1-5, 2020. The investigation revealed multiple GDPR violations including unlawful processing, lack of transparency, incorrect DPIA conduct, flawed anonymization implementation, inadequate security measures, and role confusion between companies. The authority imposed €6M fine on COSMOTE with data processing interruption and destruction orders, plus €3.25M fine on OTE.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The decision mentions Article 83(2) criteria were considered but does not provide specific details about which factors were aggravating or mitigating. The authority imposed significant fines based on the identified violations.
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Vodafone claimed processing was based on contract necessity; DPA found it was actually for promotional purposes and not necessary for contract execution.
a75_case_summary: Vodafone transmitted customer data to advertising company for promotional parcel sending despite customer objection; DPA found processing violated legality and transparency principles as it wasn't contractually necessary; fined €10,000 and ordered to provide full information and objection possibility.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Piraeus Bank sent Winbank Alerts notifications containing complainant's personal data to a third party due to incorrect email declaration by co-beneficiary. Bank failed to stop notifications despite being informed and instead instructed complainant on correction procedures. Authority found breaches of confidentiality principle (Art 5(1)(f)) and accuracy principle (Art 5(1)(d)), plus breach notification obligations (Arts 33-34). Fine imposed for continued non-compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Authority found aggravating factors including nature/gravity of breach (continued sending after notification) and lack of technical/organizational measures (no email verification). No mitigating factors discussed. Art 83(2) factors not systematically addressed.
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for employee monitoring but the DPA found processing unlawful due to use outside working hours for locating the complainant.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR;Opinion 2/2017 on data processing at work;WP 253 Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: Company X installed a geolocation system in an employee's vehicle but failed to provide complete information about its operation. An employee used the system outside working hours to locate the complainant during leave. The DPA found violations of processing legality and transparency obligations under Articles 5(1)(a), 12, 13 and accountability principle.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. The nature of the violation was aggravating as it involved location data. The incident being isolated, corrective actions taken, and being a first-time offender were mitigating factors. The violation directly affecting a data subject was aggravating while being due to individual employee action was mitigating.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the General Regulation
a75_case_summary: Alpha Bank S.A. failed to implement security policies when an employee transferred departments, allowing continued system administrator access from 2015-2022. This led to unauthorized access to 6,167 employees' sensitive data including payroll, evaluations, and health information. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f) and 32 GDPR due to inadequate security measures and monitoring. A €3,000 fine was imposed considering both aggravating and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included prolonged unauthorized access capability and processing of special category health data. Mitigating factors included post-incident security enhancements, actions against involved employees, external investigation cooperation, and limited data leakage consequences. The fine was set at the low end of the range due to minor gravity.
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Dating agency Anoixis sent unsolicited marketing SMS without consent or prior business relationship. Controller failed to cooperate with authority by not responding to requests or attending hearings. Authority imposed €45,000 fine for violations of Greek Law 3471/2006 Article 11 and GDPR Article 31.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Authority considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, intentional/negligent character as aggravating, previous infringements as aggravating, and lack of cooperation as aggravating. Other factors not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: ELPEDISON ELECTRICITY GENERATION SOLE PERSON ANONYMOUS COMPANY
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that legal bases for processing included consent (Article 6(1)(a)), contract necessity (Article 6(1)(b)), legal obligation (Article 6(1)(c)), and legitimate interests (Article 6(1)(f)) depending on the specific processing context, but noted deficiencies in consent validation and legitimate interest assessments.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor;Opinion 4/2007 on the concept of personal data;Opinion 5/2019 on the interaction between the ePrivacy Directive and the GDPR;Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA found Elpedison, an electricity company, violated GDPR Article 32 by failing to adequately control processors making promotional calls. Forty complaints revealed call centers made unauthorized calls to numbers on the opt-out registry due to technical/human errors. Elpedison received a €127,709 fine for insufficient processor oversight and was ordered to implement an audit procedure. Three call centers (Call Experts, Zitatel, PLEGMA) also received fines for GDPR violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered mitigating factors including gradual improvements by Elpedison, difficulties implementing registry provisions, and operational changes by Zitatel. Aggravating factors included call centers' main activity being telemarketing (should know framework) and PLEGMA's previous reprimand. Fines were deemed effective, proportionate, and dissuasive.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR for legitimate interests in reporting clergy misconduct. The DPA found this basis invalid for four recipients who lacked competence and for all non-clergy complainants, as the communication was not necessary or appropriate.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: An individual sent a letter with extensive personal data of six complainants (three clergy, three civilians) to six ecclesiastical authorities regarding a neighborhood dispute. The DPA found Article 6(1)(f) GDPR violated as communication was unnecessary and inappropriate for four recipients lacking competence and for all non-clergy data subjects. The fine was reduced due to negligence rather than intent, limited data scope, and no material damage shown.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was neutral (limited scope, no material damage); intent/negligence was mitigating (negligence not intent); mitigation actions were mitigating (strictly personal delivery); previous infringements were mitigating (no prior complaints). Other factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: ELTA suffered a cyberattack resulting in unauthorized access and data leakage to Dark Web affecting 4-5 million individuals. The Authority found breaches of Articles 5(1)(f) and 32 GDPR due to inadequate security measures. The fine was calculated at 1% of annual turnover considering both aggravating and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The Authority systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included gravity/duration, inadequate technical measures, and categories of data affected. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority, and financial difficulties. The fine was set at the lower end of the range due to mitigating circumstances.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for security purposes, but the DPA found this invalid as the surveillance was excessive and infringed disproportionately on employees' rights.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA found a small accounting company violated GDPR by installing a CCTV camera that monitored the entire office space rather than just the entrance. The camera allowed real-time remote monitoring by the owner, which was deemed excessive for security purposes and infringed on employee rights. The DPA rejected the legitimate interest claim under Article 6(1)(f) and found breaches of data minimization principles under Article 5(1)(c).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered aggravating factors: the nature/gravity of infringement and inadequate technical measures. Mitigating factors: small company size, camera no longer operational, first violation, and economic impact of COVID-19 pandemic.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent and legitimate interests as legal bases; the DPA found consent invalid due to power imbalance in employment relationship; legitimate interests were not properly substantiated as necessary and proportionate.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 2/2017 of the Working Group of article 29;Guidelines 2/2019 of the European Council on Data Protection;Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines and the implementation and setting of administrative fines for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679 WP253
a75_case_summary: A private tutoring center employer continuously monitored an employee's online teaching sessions via Zoom despite explicit objections. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(2), 13, and 21 GDPR for unlawful processing, lack of transparency, and failure to honor the right to object. The employer failed to establish a valid legal basis as consent was invalid due to power imbalance and legitimate interests were not properly substantiated.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including the gravity of violating fundamental principles (aggravating), the negligent rather than intentional character (mitigating), and no previous infringements (mitigating). The fine was imposed considering these factors and the need for proportionality and deterrence.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: MZN HELLAS SOCIETE ANONYME COMMERCIAL COMPANY
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed initial approval from previous transaction but the DPA found the objection via email was valid regardless of automated SMS opt-out mechanism; the controller failed to properly facilitate data subject rights exercise.
a75_case_summary: The DPA found MZN HELLAS violated GDPR by failing to honor a data subject's objection to marketing communications sent via email and SMS; the company claimed technical errors but lacked proper deletion procedures; violations included Articles 17, 21(2), 12(3) and 25(1); a €20,000 fine was imposed considering aggravating and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration and technical measures as aggravating; actions to mitigate damage, first infringement, and Covid-19 circumstances as mitigating; other factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The Municipality claimed processing was justified for journalistic purposes and citizen information under Article 28 of Law 4624/2019. The DPA found the processing violated the minimization principle as the data published (professional status, workplace, email content) were not necessary for the stated purposes and could have been achieved by milder means.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Municipality of Patras published a complainant's personal data (name, profession, workplace, political beliefs, email content) on its official website regarding a school committee decision. The DPA found this violated the data minimization principle under Article 5(1)(c) GDPR as the data exceeded what was necessary for citizen information purposes. The fine was imposed considering the violation of a fundamental principle and the Municipality's cooperation in removing the content.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the violation of a fundamental principle aggravating, while the Municipality's cooperation, lack of previous violations, and removal of content were mitigating factors. The data not being special categories was neutral. The fine was proportionate to the gravity of the violation.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller failed to demonstrate any legal basis for processing; violated accountability principle by not being able to substantiate lawfulness of processing
a75_case_summary: New York College S.A. made unsolicited marketing calls to unemployed individuals without proper legal basis; failed to demonstrate compliance with GDPR principles; violated transparency and accountability requirements; could not satisfy data subject's access request.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Authority considered nature of infringement aggravating; lack of technical measures aggravating; no previous infringements mitigating; not special categories data mitigating; damage to citizen's feeling aggravating; fine set at €5,000 based on 2018 turnover of €5,972,436.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful but the DPA found violations of security principles; no specific legal basis discussion was made regarding Articles 6(1) grounds; the focus was on security failures and breach notification obligations.
a75_case_summary: The Municipality of Alimos experienced a data breach where personal files were accessible via URL manipulation; the DPA found security failures, inadequate processor oversight, and delayed breach notifications; fines were imposed for violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 25(1), 28(3), 33(4), and 34(1)-(2); the processor was also fined for security and contract violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically; aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, negligence, poor technical measures, and lack of cooperation; mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage and no previous violations; the processor's small size was considered mitigating.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: CAREER SOLE SHAREHOLDER TECHNOLOGY SOCIETE ANONYME CURATOR, COMMERCIAL PROMOTION AND EXPLOITATION OF SPECIAL PUBLICATIONS
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed the complainant had provided his information originally, but the DPA found violations regarding failure to honor deletion requests and objection to marketing communications due to technical errors.
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA found CAREER SA violated GDPR Articles 17+21(2) and 25(1) by failing to honor a data subject's deletion request and objection to marketing communications due to a technical error that persisted for 6 months and affected 79 data subjects. The company had inadequate procedures to ensure data deletion rights were protected. A €5,000 fine was imposed considering the duration, number affected, company turnover, but also mitigation for first offense, corrective actions, and COVID-19 economic impact.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including: aggravating factors were the duration (6 months) and number of data subjects affected (79); mitigating factors were it being the first offense, actions taken to correct the problem, and the unfavorable COVID-19 economic situation.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: MZN HELLAS ANONYMI ATHLITIKI EMPORIKI ETEIRIA
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA partially revoked its previous decision against MZN HELLAS for sending unsolicited marketing SMS after the complainant objected. New evidence showed the violation was due to employee negligence rather than inadequate procedures. The fine was reduced from €20,000 to €5,000 for violations of Articles 17, 21(3), and 12(3), while the Article 25(1) violation finding was revoked.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered mitigating factors including that the violation was due to negligence not fraud, the company had appropriate procedures in place, it was the first violation, and the adverse financial situation due to Covid-19. The violation related to data subject rights exercise was considered aggravating in the original decision.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Hellenic DPA fined a company €15,000 for illegal video surveillance in employee offices and workplace kitchen. The system allowed the manager to display or conceal camera feeds on their computer screen. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(b), and 5(2) GDPR and ordered camera removal and data deletion.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: doValue Greece Anonymous Loan and Credit Claims Management Company
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(b) contract execution as legal basis for processing. The DPA found this invalid as court decisions had discharged the complainant from all debts, eliminating any contractual basis for the processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the application and determination of administrative fines for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679 WP253
a75_case_summary: A debt management company made continuous phone calls to a complainant regarding debts that had been discharged through court proceedings under Law 3869/2010. The DPA found no legal basis for processing under Article 6 GDPR as court decisions had eliminated both guarantor and general partner liability. The company also violated Article 12(2) by refusing to process data subject rights requests based on pretextual identification issues.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the continuous nature of violations aggravating, the absence of previous violations mitigating, and that no special categories of data were affected as neutral. The violations fell under the upper category of administrative fines under Article 83(5)(a) and (b).
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found violations of legal basis principles under Article 5(1)(a) but did not specifically assess the validity of any particular legal basis claimed by the controller.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 of the ESPD for the calculation of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: PPC S.A. violated GDPR by failing to properly handle a customer's data correction and deletion requests regarding disputed property debts. The company initially assured the complainant of corrections but continued sharing his data with debt collection firms. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (d), 12, 16, and 17, imposing €25,000 in total fines on PPC and €3,000 on Athens Municipality for transparency violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and seriousness of violations concerning fundamental principles of legality and accuracy as aggravating factors. Other Article 83(2) criteria were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Hellenic DPA conducted an on-site inspection at OASA regarding its Automatic Fee Collection System; Found violations of Article 5(1)(e) storage limitation principle; Issued €50,000 fine for storage limitation violation and reprimands for Articles 25(1) and 35(1); Ordered compliance regarding data retention times and review of impact assessment.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The defendant lawyer claimed the access request was manifestly unfounded and excessive under Article 12(5)(b) GDPR, but the DPA found this claim unjustified as the lawyer failed to respond at all and bears the burden of proof for such refusal.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 01/2022 on data subjects' rights – Right of access;Guidelines 04/2022 for the calculation of administrative fines under the General Regulation;WP29 Guidelines WP 253 on administrative fines
a75_case_summary: A lawyer failed to respond to a client's repeated access requests from 2019-2021 regarding case files containing personal data. The DPA found violations of Article 15 (right of access) and Article 31 (cooperation obligation), noting the lawyer's complete non-response and lack of cooperation during the investigation. The DPA imposed two €700 fines totaling €1400 based on the prolonged duration, isolated nature, and lack of financial benefit from the violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included long duration of violation and non-cooperation with authority. Mitigating factors included no previous infringements and isolated nature. Neutral factors included that no special category data was involved and only one data subject affected.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: Intermunicipal Water Supply and Sewerage Company X
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under national law provisions; the DPA found violation of data minimization principle regardless of legal basis; examination of legal bases was omitted due to violation of Article 5 principles.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 1/2010 on the concepts of controller and processor; Guidelines for the application and determination of administrative fines WP253; Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: A municipal water company disclosed an employee's COVID-19 health data to multiple internal recipients and an external civil protection directorate without necessity. The DPA found three separate violations of Article 5(1)(c) data minimization principle. The company was ordered to implement internal data access policies and fined €1,000 for the external disclosure violation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: nature of violation (fundamental principle), special category data, and negligence. Mitigating factors included: short duration, no financial damage, no previous violations, actions to mitigate consequences, and the company's public benefit purpose with deficit financial statements.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: Association for people with autism spectrum disorders "THE SHIELD OF DAVID"
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found violations of lawful basis requirements through improper data transfers without prior information to data subjects, but did not explicitly assess specific Article 6 legal bases claimed by the controller.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on processing of personal data through video devices;Guidelines 01/2022 on the rights of data subjects – Right of access;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the General Regulation;WP 253 Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The DPA found violations regarding failure to provide CCTV footage of a minor child despite access request, unauthorized transfer of sensitive health data to a third party without parental consent, and improper dissemination of court decision about the child to multiple recipients. The defendant failed to demonstrate that providing the footage would adversely affect employees' rights and did not cooperate effectively with the Authority.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of infringements (basic GDPR principles), involvement of minor's sensitive data, and lack of cooperation as aggravating factors. The defendant's status as a non-profit association fully funded by the Ministry of Health was considered mitigating.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Authority investigated complaint about processing of photo showing complainant's car license plate. Found breaches of Article 5 and Article 15 GDPR. Imposed two €10,000 fines totaling €20,000.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Bavarian DPA

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the processing unlawful as the bank disclosed complainant's credit card transactions to his wife without legal basis, violating principles of legality and confidentiality.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 18/2018 on Personal data breach notification under Regulation;Guidelines 09/2022 for the notification of incidents of violation;Guidelines 04/2022 for the calculation of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: Alpha Bank unlawfully disclosed complainant's credit card transactions to his wife without legal basis. The bank failed to properly investigate the breach incident, delayed handling for months, and incorrectly assessed the risk as negligible. The DPA found violations of Article 5(1)(a) and (f) GDPR and Article 33 GDPR, imposing fines totaling €60,000.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included multi-month delay, indifference to compliance, transferring responsibility to data subject, and underestimating consequences. Mitigating factors included isolated incident and no previous similar violations. Neutral factor was adequate organizational measures in place.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA fined a political candidate €1,000 for sending unsolicited SMS campaign messages without proper consent. The candidate obtained phone numbers from professional contacts rather than previous political engagement, violating Article 11 of Law 3471/2006. The DPA found no prior consent or legitimate previous contact, though noted the candidate provided opt-out mechanisms and cooperated with the investigation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the intentional nature of the violation and awareness of legal requirements as aggravating factors. Cooperation with the authority, provision of opt-out mechanisms, and no prior infringements were mitigating factors. The fine was deemed proportionate to the gravity of the infringement.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR for political communication. The DPA found this invalid as patient data processing for political purposes was incompatible with original medical purposes and patients could not reasonably expect such use.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 1/2023 for the processing of personal data for the purpose of communication of a political nature;Guidelines for the application and determination of administrative fines for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679 (WP 253)
a75_case_summary: A doctor used patient data from Hospital X for political campaign SMS messages without legal basis. The DPA found violations of Article 5(1)(a) principles (lawfulness, fairness, transparency) and Article 12(2) (facilitating rights exercise). The doctor failed to document data origins and presented contradictory claims during investigation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating (special health data, many affected subjects, long duration). Intentional/negligent character was aggravating (gross negligence by medical professional). Cooperation was aggravating (contradictory claims, disorientation attempts). Data categories were aggravating (health data). Other factors were aggravating (ignorance of GDPR by medical professional).
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA imposed a €2000 fine on a political candidate for sending unsolicited political emails without consent. The candidate obtained email addresses through professional relationships rather than previous political contact, violating Article 11 of Law 3471/2006. The DPA found the processing unlawful as data was obtained for one purpose (professional) but used for another (political campaigning).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the lack of consent and improper data sourcing as aggravating. Cooperation with authorities and no prior infringements were mitigating. The fine was deemed proportionate to the gravity of the infringement.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Vodafone Greece sanctioned for SIM swap security breaches; Multiple complaints about unauthorized SIM card replacements; Found violations of integrity/confidentiality and accountability principles; Ordered to implement compliance measures
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors; Nature/gravity/duration and intentional/negligent character were aggravating; Actions to mitigate damage and cooperation were mitigating; Technical measures were aggravating
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the implementation and determination of administrative fines for the purposes of regulation 2016/679 WP253
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA fined Municipal Transport Company of Rhodes "RODA" €8,000 for GDPR violations. The company breached Article 5(1)(c) by including unnecessary information (dismissal for criminal act) in an employment certificate. It also violated Articles 12(3) and 15 by failing to respond to a data subject's access request for CCTV footage and not informing him about the status of his request.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Authority investigated unauthorized access incidents involving mobile phone subscriber data following SIM card change requests. The breaches resulted from insufficient security measures or faulty implementation of identification processes. A fine of €150,000 was imposed for violations of Article 12 of Law 3471/2006.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller did not invoke any GDPR legal basis and was unable to prove legality of processing; transmission occurred before law was officially published and in force
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 of the European Data Protection Board for the calculation of administrative fines for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The National Intelligence Service transmitted employee personal data to other government bodies one day before the relevant law was officially published. The DPA found violations of Article 5(1)(a) (lawfulness) as processing occurred without proper legal basis, and Article 13 (information obligations) as the data subject was not informed. The DPA imposed a €5,000 fine for these violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered violation of fundamental principles as aggravating and negligence rather than fraud as mitigating. The controller's responsive cooperation was neutral. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Hellenic DPA examined complaints from 12 former shareholders of OASTH regarding publication of their names in a press conference and press release. The Authority found most publications justified by public interest but imposed €3,000 fine for publishing two unjustified names. An additional €7,000 fine was imposed for violations of Articles 12 and 13 of Law 2472/1997 regarding data subject rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subjects' rights – Right of access;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Guidelines for the application and determination of administrative fines for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679 WP253
a75_case_summary: A tutoring school failed to respond to a father's access request regarding his minor child's educational data and tax documents. The DPA found violations of Article 15 (right of access) and Article 12 (transparency obligations) for not providing the requested information, and Article 31 (cooperation with supervisory authority) for inadequate responses to the DPA's inquiries. The DPA imposed separate fines totaling €3,000 for these violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the violation category (highest prescribed), deprivation of access rights, long duration, and non-cooperation with authority. Mitigating factors included negligence rather than intent, affecting only one data subject, no previous violations, no financial benefit obtained, and the defendant's SME status.
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: Ministry of Climate Crisis and Civil Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found violations of multiple GDPR articles without discussing specific legal bases; the controller failed to comply with GDPR requirements since establishment.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 04/2022 on calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA found multiple GDPR violations by the Ministry of Climate Crisis and Civil Protection, including failure to appoint a DPO, lack of cooperation with the authority, and non-compliance with transparency, security, and accountability requirements. The ministry claimed organizational challenges as a newly established entity but the DPA rejected this justification. Administrative fines totaling €50,000 were imposed for violations of Articles 31, 37, 12, 32, 5, 25, and 30.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included long duration of violations, national level operations, lack of notification to authority, and reluctance to cooperate. Mitigating factors included eventual questionnaire submission and no previous violations. The controller's eventual compliance efforts were noted but insufficient to avoid sanctions.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest for marketing; DPA found consent invalid and legitimate interest invalid due to lack of proper information about secondary purpose; Processing incompatible with original purpose without proper legal basis.
a75_case_summary: A telephone sales company used customer data collected during purchases for marketing purposes without proper consent or legitimate interest basis; DPA found violations including lack of transparency about secondary purpose, failure to respect objections, and unclear controller identity; The company failed to demonstrate proper procedures for handling objection requests; A €20,000 fine was imposed for these GDPR violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Hellenic Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: Gas station failed to provide access to CCTV footage of complainant's minor child and transmitted footage to police without informing data subject. Authority found violations of access rights and transparency obligations regarding further processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: ZENITH - Gas Supply Company of Thessaloniki, Thessaly SA
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Authority received 17 complaints about illegal marketing calls promoting ZENITH's gas supply services. The processor One Way made calls to subscribers registered in the do-not-call registry due to an implementation error. ZENITH received a reprimand for processor oversight violations while One Way received a €30,000 fine for security and processing arrangement failures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: The Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests but failed to document them; the DPA found no valid legal basis as consent was not obtained, contract basis was invalid, and legitimate interests lacked transparency and right to object mechanisms.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 on calculation of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA found National Bank of Greece violated GDPR transparency obligations by storing transaction history on card chips without informing customers. The bank failed to comply with a 2018 recommendation to inform customers and provide opt-out mechanisms. The DPA imposed a €20,000 fine considering the intentional nature, large scale, and continuous duration of the violation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: aggravating factors included intentional violation, large number of data subjects, continuous duration, and economic nature of data; mitigating factors included actions to gradually stop processing and no financial benefit/loss; neutral factors were not explicitly discussed.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed public task as legal basis. The DPA found the reference to consent invalid for public authority processing, but validated the public task basis under Article 6(1)(e) for the tourism support program.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 7/2020 on concepts of controller and processor;WP29 Guidelines on administrative fines (WP253)
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA fined the Ministry of Tourism €75,000 for GDPR violations related to a data breach in the tourism4all.gov.gr platform. The breach involved unauthorized disclosure of personal data including health information to third parties during user authentication. Violations included failure to notify the breach, inadequate security measures, lack of proper processor contracts, and delayed DPO appointment. The DPA found the Ministry responsible as controller despite technical implementation by other government entities.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of breach, negligent character, inadequate technical measures, and delayed cooperation. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage and no previous infringements. The breach involved special category data which was aggravating.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: INFO COMMUNICATION SERVICES ADVERTISING - PROMOTIONAL - COMMERCIAL - RESEARCH AND PUBLICATIONS MONOPROSOOPI IKE
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent was obtained through participation forms; DPA found consents invalid due to lack of verification procedures and inability to prove consent for specific complaints; DPA determined automated marketing calls required prior consent under national law.
a75_case_summary: Greek DPA fined INFO COMMUNICATION SERVICES €30,000 for making automated marketing calls and sending SMS without valid consent and failing to properly identify itself to data subjects. The company claimed it obtained consent through participation forms but DPA found no verification procedures and invalid consents. Violations included Articles 13-14 GDPR and Article 11 of Greek Law 3471/2006 on unsolicited communications.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered financial gain from processing, lack of complaint procedures, untimely responses to authority, and ignorance of legal framework as aggravating factors. No mitigating factors discussed. Art 83(2) factors were not systematically addressed.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller did not claim a specific legal basis; the DPA found violations related to security measures and data protection by design rather than legal basis justification.
a75_case_summary: The Municipality of Alimos experienced a data breach where personal files were accessible through URL manipulation. The DPA found multiple security failures including inadequate technical measures, poor processor oversight, and delayed breach notifications. Fines were imposed for violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 32(1), 28(3), 33(4), and 34(1)-(2).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, technical measures deficiencies, and cooperation issues. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage, no previous violations, and the processor's small company size.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for biometric data processing; DPA found consent invalid as processing derives from compulsory law in exercise of public authority; Valid legal bases should be Article 6(1)(c) or (e) GDPR.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines for the application and determination of administrative fines for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679 (WP 253); Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The Greek DPA found violations regarding the issuance of new identity cards. The Ministry of Citizen Protection failed to provide proper information to data subjects, conducted incorrect information practices, and violated data minimization principles. The DPA imposed fines totaling €150,000 for violations of Articles 13-14 and 35(1) GDPR, and ordered documentation of data inclusion necessity within six months.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of violations as serious aggravating factors, affecting accountability obligations and data subject rights. The large number of affected subjects (all Greek citizens) was aggravating. The controller's steps toward compliance following DPA intervention were considered mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Vodafone GmbH was fined €45 million total for data protection violations. €15 million fine for inadequate monitoring of partner agencies (Article 28(1) GDPR) and €30 million for authentication vulnerabilities in online portal/hotline (Article 32(1) GDPR). The company cooperated fully, implemented improvements, and paid the fines.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered security deficiencies as aggravating and the company's cooperation, remedial actions, and subsequent investments in IT modernization as mitigating factors.
authority_name_norm: BfDI

a2_authority_name: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller processed health data and works council interest information without proper legal basis; the DPA found this processing unlawful as it exceeded permissible employment relationship context; health data processing without legal basis constituted particularly serious infringement
a75_case_summary: Company maintained illegal employee tracking list during probation periods containing health data and works council interest information; supervisor created list on management instructions rating employees as "critical" or "very critical"; processing violated GDPR as data exceeded permissible employment context; health data processing without legal basis constituted particularly serious infringement
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered company turnover and number of affected employees as aggravating; processing health data without legal basis as particularly serious aggravating factor; company cooperation with DPA and voluntary cessation of violation as mitigating factors
authority_name_raw: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a7_defendant_name: Subsidiary of a Berlin e-commerce group
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A Berlin e-commerce subsidiary was fined €525,000 for appointing a DPO with conflict of interest. The DPO was also managing director of service companies processing personal data for the same company, creating self-monitoring situation. Despite a 2021 warning, the violation persisted, leading to the fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the company's three-digit million turnover and intentional re-appointment despite warning as aggravating factors. Cooperation with the authority and self-reporting were mitigating factors. The fine assessment considered both aggravating and mitigating circumstances.
authority_name_raw: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A bank was fined €300,000 for failing to provide transparent information about an automated credit card rejection decision. The bank's algorithm rejected a customer's application without specific justification and only provided general scoring information when requested. The DPA found violations of transparency obligations and automated decision-making provisions under GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the bank's high turnover and intentional process design as aggravating factors. Cooperation, acknowledgment of violation, and implementation of process changes were considered mitigating factors. The assessment was not structured around Article 83(2) criteria.
authority_name_raw: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the processing unlawful as it served neither to exercise rights nor fulfill legal obligations from employment relationship, but rather to reprimand and expose the employee.
a75_case_summary: A Hamburg company required employees to report illness absences via email distribution list with 25 recipients including colleagues without work connection. Department head compiled and disclosed complainant's illness absences in denunciatory manner. DPA found violations of Art 32 and Art 9 GDPR for insufficient protection of sensitive health data and unnecessary disclosure. Fine imposed for unlawful processing that served neither rights exercise nor legal obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered processing of health data as aggravating factor. Extensive cooperation with supervisory authority and payment of compensation to complainant were mitigating factors. The nature of sensitive data was considered as matter of urgency.
authority_name_norm: HmbBfDI

a36_legal_basis_summary: DPA found storage of complete identity cards exceeded legal obligation under Coronavirus Testing Ordinance; no legal basis under Art 6(1)(c) for excessive data collection; test center should have known this from reading the law
a75_case_summary: Multiple Covid test centers violated GDPR; Doctor's office disposed test results in public garbage bag; Test center refused deletion requests despite HmbBfDI contact; Third center exposed test results via unsecured URLs; Fourth center scanned complete ID cards without legal basis; Fines ranged from €1,000-€2,700
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered health data nature as aggravating; lack of cooperation as aggravating; pandemic burden as mitigating; technical security failures as aggravating
authority_name_norm: HmbBfDI

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Daycare center improperly disposed of sensitive documents containing children's personal data, health information, and financial details in publicly accessible waste container; HmbBfDI found violation of Article 32(1) GDPR regarding security of processing; Fine imposed due to sensitive nature of data involving children and high misuse potential; First violation and negligent commission were considered mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration and categories of data as aggravating factors; First violation and negligent character were mitigating factors; Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: HmbBfDI

a2_authority_name: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a7_defendant_name: H&M Hennes & Mauritz Online Shop A.B. & Co. KG
a36_legal_basis_summary: The decision does not discuss specific legal bases but focuses on the extensive and unlawful nature of the employee monitoring practices that violated data protection principles.
a75_case_summary: H&M service center in Nuremberg extensively monitored employees since 2014, recording private details including holiday experiences, illnesses, diagnoses, family problems and religious beliefs. Data was stored on a network drive accessible to up to 50 managers and used to create employee profiles for employment decisions. The violation was discovered when a configuration error made data company-wide accessible in October 2019.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration and intentional character as aggravating, while the company's cooperation, remedial actions, and compensation payments were mitigating factors. The categories of personal data affected and manner of discovery were also aggravating.
authority_name_raw: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A credit institution employee streamed Valorant gameplay on Twitch, became angry with an opponent, and used his employer's customer database to access personal data to locate and threaten the opponent. The HmbBfDI found the employee responsible as controller for misusing access rights for private purposes. A mid-four-figure fine was imposed based on intentional violation and financial circumstances.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the intentional nature of the offense as aggravating and used the defendant's financial circumstances as basis for fine determination. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: HmbBfDI

a2_authority_name: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller stored personal data without any legal basis after deletion deadlines had expired, violating Articles 5(1)(a) and 6(1) GDPR by processing data without proper legal justification.
a75_case_summary: A Hamburg debt collection company stored six-digit number of personal data records for up to five years after deletion deadlines expired without legal basis. The Hamburg DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and 6(1) GDPR. The company admitted the violation and cooperated professionally, resulting in a reduced fine of €900,000.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the sensitive nature of debtor data as aggravating and the company's professional cooperation as mitigating. The fine was comparatively low due to the cooperation. Other Art 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_raw: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Vattenfall conducted non-transparent data comparisons of customer invoices to prevent abuse of bonus contracts affecting 500,000 people; HmbBfDI found violations of transparency obligations under Articles 12-13 GDPR; fine was reduced due to cooperation and immediate cessation; new transparent procedure balances customer rights and company interests.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed aggravating factor of large number affected (500,000 cases) and mitigating factors including extensive cooperation, immediate cessation of practice, and compliance with new procedure; fine was significantly reduced due to mitigating factors.
authority_name_raw: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: State Commissioner for Data Protection Lower Saxony
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for profiling customers for advertising purposes. The DPA found this legal basis invalid because advertising purposes cannot justify profiling through large database evaluations under legitimate interests, and customers' interests prevail in the balancing test.
a75_case_summary: A bank was fined €900,000 for profiling customers for advertising purposes without consent. The bank analyzed digital usage behavior and enriched data with credit agency information to identify customers inclined toward digital media. The DPA found legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) invalid for advertising profiling, as customers' interests prevail and consent is required.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered that the company had not used the evaluation results as mitigating, and cooperation throughout the process as mitigating. No other Article 83(2) factors were explicitly discussed.
authority_name_raw: State Commissioner for Data Protection Lower Saxony
authority_name_norm: State Commissioner for Data Protection Lower Saxony

a2_authority_name: State Commissioner for Data Protection of Lower Saxony
a36_legal_basis_summary: Company claimed legitimate interest for theft prevention but DPA found surveillance was neither limited in time nor specific to suspected individuals, making it disproportionate and unlawful.
a75_case_summary: notebooksbilliger.de AG monitored employees for 2+ years via video surveillance covering workplaces, sales rooms, warehouses and common areas without legal basis. Company claimed theft prevention but DPA found surveillance was neither time-limited nor specific to suspected individuals, and storage duration (60 days) was excessive. Surveillance also affected customers in seating areas, violating proportionality principles.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_raw: State Commissioner for Data Protection of Lower Saxony
authority_name_norm: State Commissioner for Data Protection of Lower Saxony

a2_authority_name: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information in Baden-Württemberg
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) but DPA found it invalid because no prior business relationship existed, owners couldn't expect data would be used for advertising, and land register access requires concrete contract negotiations not mere acquisition interest.
a75_case_summary: Property developer and surveyor fined for illegal land register data collection and marketing use. Surveyor accessed electronic land register to identify hundreds of property owners without knowledge and passed data to developer who contacted owners with purchase offers without providing required Article 14 information about data origin.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered number of people affected and type of data as aggravating factors, while cooperation in fine procedure was mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion.
authority_name_raw: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information in Baden-Württemberg
authority_name_norm: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information in Baden-Württemberg

a2_authority_name: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information Baden-Württemberg
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: VfB Stuttgart 1893 AG was fined €300,000 for negligent breach of accountability under Article 5(2) GDPR. The club supported educational measures, cooperated extensively with authorities, and is implementing organizational and technical data protection improvements. VfB is also taking measures to educate young people about data protection through school projects and youth team training.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed several mitigating factors including the club's cooperation with authorities, willingness to improve data protection measures, and initiatives to educate youth about data protection. The negligent character was considered mitigating rather than aggravating. The nature/gravity was discussed as aggravating.
authority_name_raw: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information Baden-Württemberg
authority_name_norm: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information Baden-Württemberg

a2_authority_name: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information Baden-Württemberg
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Knuddels GmbH & Co. KG operated an internet chat platform and stored user passwords in plain text, violating Article 32(1)(a) GDPR. A hacker attack in July 2018 resulted in the theft of 1.8 million user records containing unencrypted passwords. The DPA found Knuddels knowingly stored passwords insecurely despite awareness of security standards, but mitigated the fine due to good cooperation, transparency, and investments in improved security measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature/gravity of storing plain text passwords knowingly and the intentional character. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage through transparency and cooperation, no previous infringements, good cooperation with authority, and substantial investments in security improvements. The data breach notification manner was mitigating.
authority_name_raw: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information Baden-Württemberg
authority_name_norm: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information Baden-Württemberg

a2_authority_name: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information Bremen
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller processed data without legal basis; DPA found processing of special category data unlawful; GDPR prohibits collection of such data in most cases
a75_case_summary: BREBAU GmbH processed over 9,500 prospective tenant records without legal basis, including special category data like skin color, ethnic origin, religious affiliation, sexual orientation and health status. The company also thwarted data subject transparency requests. DPA imposed €1.9M fine but reduced it due to extensive cooperation and remediation efforts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA found violation depth aggravated fine but cooperation mitigated damage; defendant clarified facts and worked to prevent recurrence, significantly reducing fine amount.
authority_name_raw: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information Bremen
authority_name_norm: State Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information Bremen

a2_authority_name: State Commissioner for Data Protection Lower Saxony
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Volkswagen was fined €1.1M for GDPR violations related to testing driver assistance systems. The company failed to provide proper signage informing road users about data collection, lacked a data processing agreement with its service provider, conducted no DPIA, and had inadequate documentation of technical measures. The DPA noted the processing itself was lawful as it served accident prevention purposes, and Volkswagen cooperated extensively and remedied the defects.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the processing purpose (accident prevention) as mitigating, cooperation as mitigating, and lack of organizational measures as aggravating. The violations were described as low-severity and not ongoing.
authority_name_raw: State Commissioner for Data Protection Lower Saxony
authority_name_norm: State Commissioner for Data Protection Lower Saxony

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent from data brokers for marketing but could not provide individual proof; DPA found consent invalid as it was not specific, informed, or properly documented.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency within the meaning of Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: EDF was fined for multiple GDPR violations including invalid consent for electronic marketing from data brokers, insufficient information transparency, failures in responding to data subject rights requests, and inadequate data security measures using obsolete password hashing functions. The company had over 25 million customers and significant resources but failed to implement proper controls. The DPA acknowledged EDF's remediation efforts but imposed a €600,000 fine considering the seriousness and scope of violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and seriousness of violations as aggravating, while the company's cooperation and remedial actions were mitigating. The company's significant resources and scale of operations were also considered in determining the proportionate fine amount.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Liberties

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Computing and Liberties
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: CNIL sanctioned Microsoft Ireland Operations Limited for cookie violations on Bing search engine. The company deposited MUID cookie without user consent for advertising fraud prevention purposes and lacked equivalent refusal mechanism to accept cookies. The DPA found violations of Article 82 of French Data Protection Act implementing ePrivacy Directive.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration (aggravating), intentional/negligent character (aggravating), actions to mitigate damage (mitigating), technical measures (aggravating), cooperation (neutral), categories of data (aggravating), compliance with prior orders (aggravating), and other factors (aggravating).
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Computing and Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Computing and Liberties

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Civil Liberties
a36_legal_basis_summary: Google claimed consent as legal basis for advertising personalization processing; DPA found consent not validly obtained due to lack of transparency, information fragmentation, and pre-ticked default settings that didn't constitute specific positive action
a75_case_summary: CNIL fined Google €50 million for GDPR violations related to Android account creation process. The DPA found Google failed to provide transparent information about data processing purposes (particularly advertising personalization) and did not obtain valid consent for ad personalization. The violations concerned massive data processing operations affecting millions of users through scattered information architecture and pre-ticked default settings.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to ongoing violations affecting fundamental rights. The categories of personal data affected were aggravating due to the massive and intrusive nature of processing. Other aggravating factors included the scale of processing and economic model benefits.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Information Technology and Civil Liberties
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Information Technology and Civil Liberties

a2_authority_name: Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: SERGIC failed to implement appropriate security measures on its website, allowing unauthorized access to tenant applicants' personal documents through a URL manipulation vulnerability. The company was aware of the security flaw since March 2018 but took six months to implement a definitive fix. The CNIL found violations of Articles 5 (storage limitation) and 32 (security) of GDPR due to excessive data retention and inadequate security controls.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. The nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to the six-month vulnerability period. The intentional/negligent character was aggravating as the company prioritized system stability over security. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as the company eventually fixed the vulnerability. Technical measures were aggravating due to the fundamental security flaw. Data categories were aggravating due to sensitive personal information.
authority_name_raw: Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés
authority_name_norm: Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms
a36_legal_basis_summary: The company claimed consent as legal basis for all processing but DPA found some processing must be based on contract or legitimate interests instead;DPA found granular information about legal bases was required but not provided
a75_case_summary: CNIL found SPARTOO violated GDPR principles: excessive recording of employee calls for training;keeping bank data in calls;excessive prospect data retention;pseudonymization instead of deletion;inadequate password security;incomplete information to employees and customers;DPA imposed €250,000 fine and compliance order
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating;measures to mitigate damage were mitigating;technical measures were aggravating;previous infringements were mitigating;cooperation was mitigating;categories of data were aggravating;other factors were mitigating
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: guidelines on transparency within the meaning of the Regulation
a75_case_summary: CNIL sanctioned Carrefour Banque for GDPR violations including unfair processing by transmitting more personal data than disclosed to subscribers; failure to provide easily accessible information about data processing; and automatic cookie placement without consent. The company cooperated fully and corrected all violations before the hearing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and gravity of violations as aggravating, while cooperation and remedial actions were mitigating. The fine was set at €800,000 considering the company's financial capacity and compliance efforts.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: Commission Nationale de l'Informatique et des Libertés
a36_legal_basis_summary: The case focused on violations of Article 82 of French Data Protection Act (transposing ePrivacy Directive Article 5(3)), not GDPR legal bases. The DPA found cookies were placed without prior consent and without providing clear information about purposes and means to refuse.
a75_case_summary: The CNIL sanctioned Amazon Europe Core for violating French cookie rules (Article 82 of Data Protection Act). Cookies were placed on users' terminals without prior consent and without providing clear information about purposes and refusal means. The violation was particularly serious due to the scale of processing and financial benefit derived. The company was fined €35 million and ordered to bring processing into compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating (Art 83(2)(a)), measures to mitigate damage as mitigating (Art 83(2)(c)), categories of data as aggravating (Art 83(2)(g)), and financial benefit as aggravating (Art 83(2)(k)). Other factors were not discussed.
authority_name_raw: Commission Nationale de l'Informatique et des Libertés
authority_name_norm: Commission Nationale de l'Informatique et des Libertés

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A medical practitioner configured his home network to allow remote access to medical imaging data but failed to implement basic security measures, leaving medical images and patient data publicly accessible for approximately four months. The CNIL found breaches of Articles 32 (security) and 33 (breach notification) of GDPR, noting the sensitive nature of health data and the large number of patients affected. The practitioner immediately remedied the breach upon notification but failed to report it to CNIL as required.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The CNIL systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature/gravity/duration of breach, categories of data affected (health data), and manner of discovery (media report). Mitigating factors included cooperation with authorities and actions to mitigate damage. The fine was set at €3,000 considering the practitioner's financial capacity.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms
a36_legal_basis_summary: Company claimed legitimate interest basis for marketing but DPA found Article L.34-5 of CPCE requires specific consent basis for email marketing, excluding legitimate interest.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency within the meaning of the Regulation
a75_case_summary: CNIL sanctioned NESTOR SAS for email marketing without consent and transparency failures. Company built prospect database from professional social network data without obtaining consent. DPA found violations of Article L.34-5 CPCE and Articles 12-13 GDPR. Fine reduced due to COVID-19 impact on company finances.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, negligence, and complaints. Mitigating factors included cooperation and COVID-19 financial impact. Neutral factors not specifically mentioned.
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: CNIL found Google violated cookie consent transparency requirements; Ordered Google to clearly inform users about cookie purposes and refusal options; Google complied within deadline by implementing new information banner; No fine imposed as compliance was achieved.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_raw: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms
authority_name_norm: National Commission for Informatics and Freedoms

a2_authority_name: Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: French insurance company SGAM AG2R LA MONDIALE was fined €1.75M for violating GDPR storage limitation principle (Article 5(1)(e)) and transparency obligations (Articles 13-14). The company retained prospect data beyond its own 3-year policy and client data beyond legal retention periods, sometimes exceeding 30 years. The DPA found serious negligence regarding fundamental GDPR principles affecting millions of data subjects, including sensitive data and banking information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature/gravity/duration of violations, negligent character, inadequate technical measures, and sensitive data categories. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authorities and corrective actions taken. The company's financial situation was considered but remained positive despite decreased turnover.
authority_name_raw: Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés
