The DPA found breaches of Articles 5,6,12,26,28,30,35 and imposed corrective orders plus a €72,000 fine. The controller processed audio data in taxis without proper legal basis assessment and provided insufficient information to data subjects.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of infringement and categories of data affected. Mitigating factors included negligence rather than intent, actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority, no previous infringements, and financial impact of COVID-19 on taxi operations.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Officer
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Officer

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed offering call listening and summaries complied with GDPR; the DPA found summaries were not valid copies under Article 15(3) as they excluded personal data and did not correspond to the original recording; the DPA emphasized that listening alone does not fulfill the right of access requirement.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 guidelines on the application and imposition of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA found Suomen Avainsanat Oy violated GDPR by failing to provide proper copies of call recordings to data subjects, instead offering summaries that excluded personal data. The controller also failed to comply with a prior order from March 2021 requiring compliance with access rights. The DPA issued a reprimand and referred the case to the sanctions board, which imposed a €23,000 fine for violations of Articles 12(1), 15(3) and non-compliance with an Article 58(2)(d) order.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, intentional character, lack of technical measures, previous infringements, and poor cooperation. Mitigating factors included some actions to mitigate damage. The data categories affected were considered neutral.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Commissioner

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller did not properly implement the data subject's right of access under Article 15 and failed to provide adequate information about its role as controller. The DPA found violations of transparency obligations and data subject rights facilitation requirements.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 guidelines on the application and imposition of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: A medical clinic failed to properly implement a data subject's access request under Article 15 GDPR. The DPA found systematic violations including failure to facilitate data subject rights, inadequate transparency information, and poor cooperation with the supervisory authority. The clinic processed health data but lacked proper procedures for rights implementation and information provision. A €5,000 fine was imposed due to the serious and systematic nature of the violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: nature/duration of violation, negligent character, failure to mitigate damage, inadequate technical measures, poor cooperation, and processing of special category health data. No mitigating factors were identified. The violation was considered serious and systematic.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A psychotherapist failed to respond to a patient's data access requests under Article 15 GDPR for nearly three years despite multiple requests and DPA guidance. The DPA found violations of Article 12(3) and (4) GDPR regarding timely response to data subject requests. The controller claimed exceptional circumstances but the DPA found intentional neglect of GDPR obligations, particularly concerning sensitive health data processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: nature/duration of violation (3-year delay), intentional character, failure to mitigate damage, inadequate technical measures, lack of cooperation with DPA, and sensitive health data involved. Neutral factors included: no previous infringements and no financial benefit obtained.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Commissioner

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Legal basis discussion focused on failure to comply with supervisory order rather than processing legal basis; controller failed to provide call recording to verify lawful basis; DPA did not assess validity of any specific Article 6 legal basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the application and imposition of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: Telemarketing company failed to comply with DPA order to provide call recording to data subject under Article 15; company only complied after DPA initiated sanction proceedings; DPA imposed €8,300 fine for non-compliance with supervisory order under Article 83(6); breach considered serious due to disregard for data protection regulations and lack of cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; intentional/negligent character was aggravating; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; cooperation with authority was aggravating; compliance with prior orders was aggravating.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for contract performance under Article 6(1)(b);DPA found processing for customer account creation was not objectively necessary for online purchase contract;DPA stated contract basis should be interpreted narrowly and processing was typically for business benefit
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found Verkkokauppa.com violated storage limitation principle by requiring customer registration for single online purchases;Controller stored personal data indefinitely unless data subject requested deletion;DPA held this transferred data protection responsibility to data subjects and violated Articles 5(1)(e) and 25(2);Controller was ordered to define proper retention periods and fined €856,000
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors;Nature and duration of violation were aggravating (deliberate practice since 2018 affecting millions);Intentional character was aggravating (controller consciously implemented non-compliant procedure);Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating (planned inactive account deletion mechanism)
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful but the DPA found breaches of Articles 5(1)(f) and 32 regarding security of processing health data transmitted to third-party monitoring services.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Guidelines on the application and imposition of administrative fines under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: University Pharmacy transmitted health data (medicine browsing/purchase information) to third-party monitoring services (Google, Meta, New Relic) without adequate security measures. The DPA found breaches of Articles 5(1)(f) and 32 GDPR. The infringement lasted approximately four years during GDPR application period and affected a large number of data subjects. The penalty was imposed due to the serious nature of processing sensitive health data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/duration of infringement, intentional/negligent character, technical/organizational measures, and categories of personal data affected. Mitigating factor was that controller's revenues support education/research. Neutral factors included actions to mitigate damage and cooperation with authority.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman

a7_defendant_name: Police officer and health care worker
a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendants claimed public task basis but DPA found no need for knowledge arising from service task, making processing unlawful
a75_case_summary: Police officer and health care worker fined for unauthorized curiosity requests in government databases. Police officer accessed future spouse's information 3 times; healthcare worker researched ambulance call data at third party's request. Both violated data protection requirements despite employer training. Fines reduced due to regret and agreement to expedited procedure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered regret and agreement to expedited procedure as mitigating factors. Nature of violations was aggravating. Other Article 83(2) factors not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Inspectorate

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted inspection of Arp-Hansen Hotel Group and found approximately 500,000 customer profiles stored beyond their own deletion deadlines, some for several years. The DPA found violation of Article 5(1)(e) storage limitation principle. A fine of DKK 1,100,000 was recommended due to extensive storage without objective reasons.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Lejre Municipality was fined for inadequate security measures after uploading sensitive meeting minutes containing personal data of minors to a staff portal accessible to many employees without work-related need. The DPA found violation of security requirements and failure to notify data subjects about the breach. The fine considered the nature of violation, sensitive data type, and municipality size.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The Data Inspectorate emphasized the nature of the violation (lack of security), nature and amount of personal data affected, and municipality size as aggravating factors. The fact that the municipality self-reported the breach was considered mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: The Data Inspectorate

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: JobTeam A/S deleted personal data after receiving an access request but before responding, violating GDPR principles. The Danish Data Inspectorate reported the company to police and recommended a DKK 50,000 fine. The authority emphasized fines must be effective, dissuasive, and proportionate to the infringement.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Data Inspectorate

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Two Danish municipalities fined for inadequate security measures; Unencrypted computers containing sensitive personal data were stolen; Gladsaxe Municipality had data on 20,620 citizens stolen; Hørsholm Municipality had employee data on 1,600 individuals stolen
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The Data Inspectorate emphasized nature of infringement (lack of security), failure to encrypt as general measure, and municipality size in population and operating allowance; Recommended fines of DKK 100,000 and DKK 50,000 respectively
authority_name_norm: Data Inspectorate

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: PrivatBo AMBA distributed 424 USB keys containing confidential tenant information during a property sale process. The DPA found PrivatBo failed to implement appropriate security measures by not reviewing material before distribution. The disclosure caused significant discomfort to tenants and risked reputation damage.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed nature/gravity of infringement (AGGRAVATING), technical/organizational measures (AGGRAVATING), and categories of personal data affected (AGGRAVATING). Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically addressed.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: SIRIUS lawyers failed to implement basic security measures for remote access to IT systems containing special category data. A hacker attack compromised client information, creating serious risks to data subjects. The Danish DPA found inadequate security measures despite high-risk processing context. The firm was cooperative and implementing multifactor authentication at time of breach.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA emphasized nature/gravity of infringement and need for effective deterrent fine as aggravating factors. Cooperative behavior and ongoing security improvements were mitigating factors. Data categories affected weighed against the controller.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Agency

a7_defendant_name: National Board of Health and Welfare
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The National Board of Health and Welfare returned an unencrypted USB stick containing over 800 pages of sensitive complainant information that was lost during transit. The agency lacked guidelines for handling removable storage devices and failed to report the breach to the DPA. The DPA found inadequate security measures and recommended a DKK 100,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA emphasized the lack of encryption as an essential security measure that should be easily implemented, particularly for a state authority processing sensitive information. The agency's failure to have proper guidelines for caseworkers and the sensitive nature of the data were aggravating factors. The case involved a breach notification violation under Article 33.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: National Genome Center processed genetic data without consulting DPA despite DPIA showing high risk; DPA imposed temporary ban on data collection and restriction on processing; Violation of consultation requirement when high risk exists; Fine recommended due to seriousness but mitigated by NGC's cooperation and risk work quality.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered high risk to data subjects as aggravating; NGC's high quality risk work and active cooperation were mitigating factors; Other Art 83(2) factors not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danske Bank failed to document proper deletion procedures across 400+ systems processing millions of individuals' data. The Danish DPA initiated an own-motion investigation after the bank self-reported deletion issues. The breach concerned fundamental GDPR principles including storage limitation and accountability. A DKK 10M fine was imposed considering the scale and basic nature of the violation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating (affecting many data subjects and basic principles). Mitigating factors included bank's efforts to limit damage and active cooperation. The fine was set to be effective, proportionate and deterrent.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Vejle Municipality's dental care had automatic process sending welcome letters containing both parents' addresses without assessing disclosure necessity. This resulted in parents receiving information about other parent's address regardless of name/address protection. Danish DPA found inadequate security measures violating GDPR security requirements. Case discovered through municipality's own breach notification.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA emphasized nature/seriousness of infringement, requirement for effective/proportionate/deterrent fine, and municipality size in terms of population and operating budget as aggravating factors. The fact that municipality self-reported the breach was considered mitigating.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Company claimed legitimate interest for informing customers about employee dismissal; DPA found legitimate interest existed for informing customers employee was dismissed but not for detailed criminal offense information; Detailed description of criminal offenses was not necessary to fulfill the objective.
a75_case_summary: Company disclosed detailed criminal offense information about former employee to customers via email; DPA found legitimate interest existed for informing customers about dismissal but not for detailed criminal information; Disclosure violated data protection principles as information about criminal offenses was not necessary; Proposed fine of DKK 150,000 for unlawful processing of special category data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity (AGGRAVATING) due to criminal offense data disclosure; Categories of personal data affected (AGGRAVATING) due to special category data; Other factors not explicitly discussed in Art 83(2) framework.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Gyldendal stored information about 685,000 resigned book club members in a passive database without deletion procedures, with 395,000 records kept over 10 years. The Danish DPA found violations of storage limitation and accountability principles. The DPA reported to police and recommended DKK 1,000,000 fine due to the large scale and intentional nature of violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the violation intentional and affecting many data subjects as aggravating factors. Gyldendal's cooperation and limited database access were mitigating factors. The DPA assessed sanctions under Article 83(2) but did not systematically discuss all factors.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Lolland Municipality failed to implement basic security measures by allowing employees to disable mandatory access codes on mobile devices. A stolen work phone without access code protection exposed citizens' sensitive information including names, social security numbers, and health data. The DPA found inadequate security measures and recommended a DKK 50,000 fine, emphasizing the municipality's special responsibility to protect citizen information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA conducted Article 83(2) assessment. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of infringement, inadequate technical measures, sensitive data categories affected, and municipality's special responsibility. Mitigating factors included immediate remedial actions taken and breach self-reporting.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Medicals Nordic used WhatsApp to transmit confidential health information and social security numbers of COVID-19 test subjects. Employees used private phones and WhatsApp groups where unauthorized personnel received sensitive data, including former employees who weren't removed from groups. The Danish DPA found inadequate security measures and intentional violations due to lack of risk assessments.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA emphasized that confidential health information about many citizens was processed insecurely and shared with unauthorized persons, including former employees. Violations were considered intentional due to lack of necessary risk assessments. The nature of sensitive data and intentional character were aggravating factors.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Vejen Municipality reported stolen laptops containing unencrypted student data including information about children with special challenges. DPA investigation revealed up to 300 additional unencrypted computers in the municipality. The DPA emphasized encryption as a basic security measure and noted repeated similar violations across municipalities.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration and technical measures as aggravating factors, while cooperation and manner of discovery were mitigating. The municipality had previous similar violations which was also aggravating.
authority_name_norm: Danish Data Protection Authority

a7_defendant_name: Bank of Cyprus Public Company Ltd
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful but DPA found violations of integrity/confidentiality principles and accountability obligation due to inability to locate insurance policy containing personal data.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Personal data breach notification under Regulation 2016/679 WP 250 rev.1
a75_case_summary: Bank failed to locate complainant's insurance policy despite requests. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 5(2), 15, 32, and 33 due to inadequate security measures leading to data unavailability, failure to demonstrate accountability, and lack of breach notification. Bank claimed policy might be misplaced but couldn't prove it still existed within their systems.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included nature of breach, manner authority informed, and infringement duration. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority, actions to mitigate damage, and no financial benefit. Neutral factors included categories of data affected and number of data subjects.
authority_name_norm: Commissioner for Personal Data Protection

a2_authority_name: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Deutsche Wohnen SE violated multiple GDPR principles by storing tenant personal data indefinitely without proper purpose limitation, data minimization, or storage limitation. The housing company failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure data protection. The Berlin DPA found systematic violations across Article 5 principles due to the company's failure to establish proper data retention policies and deletion concepts. The fine was reduced from initial proposal due to cooperation and remedial actions taken.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, technical measures, and previous infringements were aggravating. Actions to mitigate damage and cooperation were mitigating. Other mitigating factors included the company's efforts to improve compliance.
authority_name_raw: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
authority_name_norm: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information

a2_authority_name: Commissioner for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for journalistic purposes. The DPA found this basis invalid because the publication of names and photos was not necessary for the journalistic purpose and overrode the data subjects' fundamental rights.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 for the calculation of administrative sanctions on the basis of GDPR 2016/679
a75_case_summary: A newspaper published names and photos of police investigators involved in detaining an elderly Turkish Cypriot woman at Larnaca airport. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(c) and 6(1)(f) as the publication was disproportionate to journalistic purposes and unnecessary for public information. The DPA imposed a €7,000 fine after weighing aggravating and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, intentional character as aggravating, actions to mitigate damage as mitigating, cooperation as mitigating, and categories of data affected as mitigating. Other factors were not discussed.
authority_name_raw: Commissioner for the Protection of Personal Data
authority_name_norm: Commissioner for the Protection of Personal Data

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access (Version 2.0)
a75_case_summary: Brivio Limited failed to respond to a data subject access request within the one-month timeframe required by Article 12(3) GDPR. The controller claimed the request was part of a pattern of manifestly unfounded requests from a law firm, but the Commissioner found each request must be assessed individually regardless of the representative. The Commissioner imposed a €2,000 fine considering both mitigating and aggravating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: the nature/gravity/duration of infringement, lack of appropriate measures, manner infringement became known, and previous infringements. Mitigating factors included: actions to mitigate damage and cooperation with supervisory authority.
authority_name_norm: Commissioner For Personal Data Protection

a2_authority_name: Commissioner for Personal Data Protection in Cyprus
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f); DPA found processing lawful since data was manifestly made public by data subjects on public sources like Google; purpose remained unchanged from original publication of business contact details
a75_case_summary: Senira Limited operated nicelocal.com website collecting business information from public sources; failed to respond to data subject erasure requests within GDPR timeframe; violated Article 12(3) by not acting on requests within one month; violated Article 31 by failing to cooperate with supervisory authority's investigation requests
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors; mitigating factors: requests eventually satisfied, no harm occurred, no sensitive data; aggravating factors: increasing complaints, lack of appropriate procedures, lack of response to preliminary decision order
authority_name_raw: Commissioner for Personal Data Protection in Cyprus
authority_name_norm: Commissioner for Personal Data Protection in Cyprus

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest for journalistic purposes; DPA found publication of photographs excessive and not necessary for public information right; violated minimization principle and invalidated legitimate interest basis
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guideline 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative sanctions on the basis of the GDPR 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Newspaper publisher Breikot Management Ltd published photographs of three complainants in four articles about their family architectural firm continuing public works despite conviction. DPA found violation of Articles 5(1)(c) and 6 GDPR as photographs exceeded journalistic necessity and minimization principle. Administrative Court upheld violation but annulled fine amount, leading to review that maintained original €3,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating; negligent character, mitigation actions, cooperation, and first offense as mitigating; data categories as neutral. Fine maintained at €3,000 after review of aggravating and mitigating factors.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
authority_name_norm: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Irish DPC conducted ex officio inspection at Aylo Freesites Ltd (formerly Mindgeek) focusing on cookie consent, biometric data processing, DPIAs and data processing agreements. Multiple GDPR breaches found including accountability, transparency, lawfulness, data minimization, storage limitation, data security and legal basis requirements. Company implemented corrective measures but fined €58,400 total for pre-compliance violations and illegal cookie use.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPC considered breaches significant as they occurred four years after GDPR implementation (aggravating). Company's compliance with recommendations and implementation of corrective measures were mitigating factors. Other Art 83(2) factors not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Commission

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Open University of Cyprus suffered a ransomware attack where hackers stole and published personal data of students, graduates, and contractors. The University failed to implement appropriate security measures and violated the accountability principle. The DPA considered mitigating factors including planned security improvements and the University's public sector status, imposing a €45,000 fine and ordering security measures implementation oversight.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered inadequate technical measures as aggravating and the University's cooperation and planned security improvements as mitigating. The University's public sector status was also considered as a mitigating factor in the sanction determination.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
authority_name_norm: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for credit assessment purposes; the DPA found violations of accuracy and storage limitation principles due to retention of data beyond legal period; key reasoning was that technical limitations and lack of resources do not excuse non-compliance with GDPR obligations.
a75_case_summary: The Housing Finance Organization retained complainant's loan application data beyond the 6-month retention period; inaccurate data from a 2020 rejected application was used in assessing a 2023 application; the DPA found violations of accuracy, storage limitation, and accountability principles; technical limitations and resource constraints were rejected as justifications for non-compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of infringement, intentional/negligent character, and failure to implement measures; mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and actions to mitigate damage; neutral factor was categories of data affected.
authority_name_raw: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
authority_name_norm: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian Insurance Bureau fined €101,000 for security failures leading to data leak of over 1 million vehicle owners' personal data. Agency found inadequate technical/organizational measures under Article 32 and failure to prescribe maximum retention periods under Article 5(1)(e). Fine reduced due to defendant's public authority status under national implementation law.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors discussed include nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, categories of personal data affected as aggravating, and other mitigating factors (public authority status). Most factors were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian Insurance Bureau fined €101,000 for GDPR violations. HUO failed to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures under Article 32, compromising personal data security. Additionally, HUO violated Article 5(1)(e) by not prescribing maximum retention periods for personal data. The fine amount considered HUO's status as a legal entity with public authority.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Agency

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal basis for processing but DPA found incorrect information regarding legal basis under Article 6(1); violation of transparency requirements under Article 13(1)
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA fined debt collection agency B2 Kapital €2,265,000 for multiple GDPR violations. Violations included: failure to properly inform data subjects about processing (Article 13); lack of processor contract for bankruptcy monitoring service (Article 28); inadequate security measures leading to data exfiltration of 77,317 individuals' sensitive financial data (Article 32). The violations lasted from 2018-2023 and were discovered through anonymous tip with USB containing exfiltrated data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration of violations; negligent character; categories of data affected; lack of cooperation; failure to implement corrective measures. Mitigating: no specific mitigating actions mentioned. The violations affected at least 132,652 data subjects with sensitive financial data.
authority_name_raw: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
authority_name_norm: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controllers claimed consent as legal basis for cookie processing but DPA found consent invalid due to cookie banner not allowing clear distinction between purposes and processing occurring before consent was given
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA imposed nine fines totaling €51,000 on controllers for GDPR violations. Gambling operators fined €15,000-€20,000 for invalid cookie consent and transparency violations. Hotels and shops fined €500-€4,000 for inadequate CCTV signage violating national implementation law requirements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controllers claimed consent for cookie processing but DPA found consent invalid due to cookie banner not allowing clear distinction between purposes and processing occurring before consent given
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA imposed nine fines totaling EUR 51,000 on controllers for GDPR violations. Two gambling/betting operators fined EUR 15,000 and EUR 20,000 for invalid cookie consent and transparency violations. Seven retail/hospitality operators fined EUR 16,000 total for inadequate CCTV signage violations under national implementation law.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA fined Zagrebačka holding €25,000 for GDPR violations. The company failed to properly inform users about legal basis and storage periods when collecting ID copies for email invoice requests. It also lacked adequate technical measures for user identification, inconsistently requiring ID documents based on email address structure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller could not demonstrate any legal basis for recording telephone conversations despite repeated requests from the Agency, violating Article 6(1) and the accountability principle under Article 5(2).
a75_case_summary: A Croatian special hospital was fined €190,000 for multiple GDPR violations. The hospital failed to implement appropriate technical measures (backups) for radiological image data, leading to irreversible loss of special category health data. It also failed to report the security breach within 72 hours, lacked a processor contract, recorded phone calls without legal basis or proper transparency, and excluded its DPO from key decisions. The hospital claimed cost concerns for backups, but the Agency found this unjustified given the sensitivity of health data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The Agency considered the nature/gravity/duration (aggravating), intentional/negligent character (aggravating), technical measures (aggravating), categories of data affected (aggravating), and actions to mitigate damage (mitigating). The hospital failed to correct irregularities, weighing against it.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Agency

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis was proven for cookie processing. The DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6(1) existed, violating the lawfulness principle.
a75_case_summary: Gambling companies processed personal data through cookies without legal basis under Article 6(1). They failed to provide adequate information under Article 13 and obtain valid consent under Article 7. The DPA imposed fines of €20,000 and €30,000 for these violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA noted consideration of Article 83(2) factors including nature, severity and duration of violation; intentional or negligent character; and degree of controller responsibility. No specific aggravating or mitigating factors were detailed.
authority_name_raw: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
authority_name_norm: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: trading company for organizing games of chance - betting games (sports betting)
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for legal obligations under anti-money laundering law, but DPA found this invalid as processing bank card copies was not necessary for compliance with legal obligations.
a75_case_summary: Controller processed bank card copies without legal basis, violating Article 6. Failed to inform data subjects about this processing, violating Article 13. Implemented inadequate technical measures for new payment service, violating Article 25. Stored data without encryption and security assessments, violating Article 32. Financial data processing created high risk to rights and freedoms.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered financial data sensitivity as aggravating. Controller's post-supervision cooperation, system improvements, and data deletion were mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis conducted.
authority_name_raw: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
authority_name_norm: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data

a7_defendant_name: hotel manager (legal entity within which the hotel operates)
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary but DPA found no legal basis existed for collecting CVC number and copy of personal documents as reservation was possible without these excessive data
a75_case_summary: Hotel collected excessive personal data (CVC numbers and ID copies) without legal basis during reservations. Failed to provide transparent information about processing through Terms and Conditions. Lacked appropriate technical/organizational security measures. Appointed hotel manager as DPO creating conflict of interest.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: HEP-Toplinarstvo stored user passwords in readable form in its database and sent users' actual passwords via email during password reset process. The controller failed to implement basic security measures like encryption or temporary password generation, exposing nearly 16,000 users to security risks. The controller also failed to cooperate with the supervisory authority by not providing necessary information and not taking remedial actions after learning of the breach.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, the intentional/negligent character as aggravating, lack of cooperation as aggravating, and failure to mitigate damage as mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA fined an information and communication company €50,000 for security failures that led to a hacker attack compromising user data. The controller failed to implement appropriate technical security measures, allowing the attacker complete system access. The violation specifically concerned Article 32(1)(b) and (d) and Article 32(2) regarding security of processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the failure to implement appropriate technical security measures as aggravating, while the controller's immediate response to resolve the security issue was mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.
authority_name_norm: Croatian Personal Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found the proportionality test inadequate and failed to prove necessity or proper balancing against data subject rights. The controller incorrectly cited national laws as legal basis instead of GDPR provisions.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Officers (WP 243 rev.01);Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines (WP 253)
a75_case_summary: The Croatian DPA fined a business data provider _ d.o.o. €40,000 for multiple GDPR violations. The company processed craft owners' personal data without proper legal basis under Article 6(1)(f), failed transparency obligations under Articles 12-14, maintained inadequate records under Article 30, and appointed a DPO with conflict of interest under Article 38. Violations were discovered through citizen complaints and DPA inspection.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to prolonged violations since 2018. Intentional character was aggravating for transparency violations, negligent for others. Previous infringements were aggravating. Cooperation was aggravating due to initial non-cooperation. No damage mitigation was neutral.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Officers;Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA found controller violated GDPR Articles 37(7) and 38(6) by appointing DPO with conflict of interest (company procurator) and failing to publish DPO contact details on website. The DPA determined procurator role involves determining purposes/means of processing, creating conflict with DPO advisory role. Fine imposed based on coordinated EDPB activity investigating DPO positions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/duration of infringement, poor cooperation with authority, failure to resolve conflict of interest. Mitigating: negligent not intentional conduct, actions to mitigate damage, no previous infringements. Neutral: manner authority became aware.
authority_name_norm: Personal Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: The defendant claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR for managing the fan page. The DPA found this invalid as commercial interests cannot override data subject rights, especially after contractual relations ended.
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found a record company violated GDPR by managing a Facebook fan page using an artist's name without legal basis after contract termination. The company claimed legitimate interests but DPA ruled commercial interests cannot override data subject rights. The defendant failed to comply with data subject's objection rights and transparency obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. Nature/gravity was aggravating due to core GDPR violations. Duration was aggravating as violations lasted over 5 months. Data categories affected was aggravating as personal identity data was involved. Other factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Autorité de protection des données

a7_defendant_name: Family Service / The National Service for Promotion of Children's Articles, NV
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent (Art. 6(1)(a)) and legitimate interests (Art. 6(1)(f)) as legal bases. The DPA found consent invalid due to lack of freedom, specificity, and informed nature. Legitimate interests were invalid due to insufficient safeguards and failure to pass balancing test.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation 216/679
a75_case_summary: The defendant operated a service providing "Pink Boxes" to expectant mothers while trading their personal data to third parties for marketing. The DPA found multiple GDPR violations including invalid consent due to non-free and non-transparent practices, inadequate legal basis for pre-2018 data processing, insufficient transparency, disproportionate retention, and lack of processor agreements. The core issue was disguising data trading activities while presenting as a beneficial service.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of infringements, intentional/negligent character, inadequate technical measures, previous infringements, categories of data affected, and need for deterrence. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage and COVID-19 economic impact. Cooperation with authority was considered neutral.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but DPA found consent not free due to lack of alternative; DPA also examined legitimate interests and found data subject interests prevailed; no valid legal basis established.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on consent within the meaning of Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Retailer required electronic ID card scanning for loyalty card creation without alternative. DPA found violations of data minimization (Article 5(1)(c)) due to processing irrelevant data like gender and national register number, and no valid legal basis (Article 6) as consent wasn't free and legitimate interests didn't prevail. Also found transparency violations (Article 13) regarding legal basis and storage period information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to fundamental principle violation and considerable impact on all customers. Also discussed categories of data as aggravating due to national register number processing. No other factors discussed.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on his public function as mayor. The DPA found the reuse of citizen contact data for electoral purposes incompatible with the original purpose of collection, violating Articles 5(1)(b) and 6(4) GDPR.
a75_case_summary: A municipal mayor reused citizen contact data collected during his official duties for electoral campaigning. The DPA found this violated purpose limitation principles under Articles 5(1)(b) and 6(4) GDPR. The breach was considered serious due to the electoral context and defendant's public position. A €5,000 fine and reprimand were imposed.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to fundamental principle violation. Intentional character was aggravating as processing was deliberate. Data categories were neutral as only identification data. Other aggravating factors included defendant's public position and electoral context.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest as legal basis for cookies used for website functionality and statistics collection. The DPA found this invalid as consent is required for non-essential cookies under Article 129 WEC and Articles 6-7 GDPR.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on consent under Regulation 2016/679;Opinion 04/2012 on exemption from consent requirement for cookies;Guidelines on transparency under Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA found a legal news website violated GDPR transparency and consent requirements. The website failed to provide proper privacy information in required languages, used pre-ticked cookie consent boxes, and lacked valid legal basis for analytics cookies. The DPA imposed a €15,000 fine considering the negligent nature, duration of infringements, and the website's 35,000 monthly readers.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including duration (aggravating), negligent character (aggravating), measures taken to mitigate (mitigating), and cooperation with authority (mitigating). The fine was set at €15,000 considering these factors and the controller's turnover.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Notification of Personal Data Breaches under Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines for Data Protection Officers (DPO)
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found defendant violated Article 38(6) GDPR by appointing DPO who also served as head of Compliance, Risk Management and Internal Audit departments, creating conflict of interest. The DPA ordered corrective measures and imposed €50,000 fine. Defendant's procedural challenges were dismissed as rights of defense were respected.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors discussed: nature/gravity/duration (aggravating), intentional/negligent character (aggravating), categories of data affected (aggravating). Other factors not discussed. Fine based on serious negligence, large-scale processing impacting millions, and duration from May 2018 to February 2020.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed consent from users was valid legal basis for processing non-users' data. DPA found consent invalid as only data subjects can consent to their own data processing. DPA also examined and rejected legitimate interest as legal basis for processing non-users' data.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 5/2009 on online social networking;Opinion 06/2014 on the concept of legitimate interest;Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data by camera
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found social media platform Y violated GDPR by processing non-users' personal data without legal basis through "invite a friend" functionality. Platform claimed user consent justified processing third-party data, but DPA ruled only data subjects can consent to their own processing. DPA also rejected legitimate interest basis as processing exceeded necessary scope and duration. Fine of €50,000 imposed for violations of Articles 5 and 6.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to serious lack of legal basis. Intentional/negligent character was aggravating as defendant was aware of issues. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as defendant removed pre-ticked options. Categories of data affected was aggravating due to processing non-users' data. Cooperation was neutral as defendant cooperated but maintained incorrect legal position.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for direct marketing to former donors. DPA found legitimate interest invalid due to failure to provide adequate safeguards and unconditional right to object as required by Article 21.4.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Recommendation 1/2020 of the Data Protection Authority concerning the processing of personal data for direct marketing purposes;Opinion 06/2014
a75_case_summary: Defendant NGO continued direct marketing to complainant despite repeated objections and erasure requests. DPA found violations of right to object to marketing (Articles 21.2-21.4), right to erasure (Article 17.1(c)), and invalid legal basis under Article 6(1)(f). Defendant failed to provide adequate safeguards and continued processing for months after complaint notification.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/duration of infringement and lack of cooperation. Mitigating: first infringement, defendant's non-profit status with limited turnover. Other factors were neutral or not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Defendant published complainant's name, address and photo on personal website without consent. Complainant repeatedly requested erasure but defendant failed to comply despite promises and formal DPA order. DPA found violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4, 17.1 and 31 GDPR for failing to respond to erasure requests and cooperate with authority.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to core GDPR rights violation and prolonged duration. Intentional/negligent character was aggravating due to ignoring requests and orders. Cooperation was aggravating due to non-response. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as defendant eventually deleted data. Other factors not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed legal obligation under Flemish decree but DPA found consent was required basis; processing was not necessary for compliance with legal obligation; only valid legal basis would have been consent under Article 6(1)(a)
a74_guidelines_referenced: Recommendation No 01/2018 of 28 February 2018 on Data Protection Impact Assessment and Prior Consultation;Manual on Data Protection Impact Assessment dating from April 2019
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found school violated GDPR by conducting well-being survey among underage pupils via Smartschool without proper legal basis; school claimed legal obligation but DPA found consent was required; violations included lack of parental consent for children under 13, insufficient transparency information, and excessive data collection; DPA ordered compliance and imposed €2000 fine considering educational context and mitigation efforts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors; nature/gravity was aggravating due to fundamental principles violation and special protection for children; defendant's efforts to provide anonymous survey were mitigating; educational non-profit status was mitigating; other factors not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed processing was due to human error; DPA found no legal basis under Article 6 applied; Processing was unlawful as none of Article 6 conditions were met
a75_case_summary: Defendant sent marketing emails to complainant due to human error mixing email addresses; Complainant exercised right of access but received inadequate response; DPA found breaches of Articles 5,6,12,15,24 GDPR; Fine imposed for inadequate response to data subject rights and unlawful processing
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors; Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; Intentional/negligent character was aggravating; Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; Technical/organizational measures were aggravating; Other factors not discussed
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under legal obligation but DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6(1) and invalidated consent under Article 8 for children's data processing without parental consent.
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA imposed €1000 fine on school for conducting well-being survey of minors via Smartschool without valid legal basis under Article 6(1) and violating Article 8 parental consent requirements. The DPA rejected defendant's claim of government exemption from fines, finding violations of data minimization principle (Article 5(1)(c)) and special protections for children's data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating (Articles 5(1)(c),6(1),8 violated), defendant's non-profit status as mitigating, and willingness to implement anonymous surveys as mitigating. Duration was limited to single survey event.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for processing electoral data to identify new residents for campaign purposes. The DPA found this invalid as the processing was not necessary for electoral purposes and the controller's interests did not outweigh data subjects' rights, especially given the use of knowledge acquired through other professional/political roles.
a75_case_summary: A local politician processed voter data from electoral rolls to create a list of new residents for targeted campaign mailings. The DPA found violations of purpose limitation (using 2012 electoral data for 2018 elections) and legitimate interests basis (using knowledge from other roles). Transparency violations occurred as the letter lacked proper controller identification and information about data processing methods.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including seriousness of infringement (aggravating), technical/organizational measures (aggravating), duration (mixed - short processing period but using old data), and deterrent effect (aggravating). Financial capacity was considered mitigating, leading to fine reduction from €5000 to €3000.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for legal defense and business continuity. The DPA found legitimate interest valid only for data less than 5 years old, invalid for older data due to lack of necessity and proportionality.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 2/2017 on data processing in the workplace;Opinion 06/2014 on the notion of legitimate interest
a75_case_summary: Former employee complained about employer's data recovery from laptop after dismissal. DPA found legitimate interest basis valid only for data less than 5 years old due to pending litigation. Violations found for right of access, erasure, restriction, objection, and lack of processor contract. Compliance order issued with €7500 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were discussed briefly. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating. Intentional character was aggravating. Other factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legitimate interest from previous contacts, but the DPA found the electoral purpose incompatible with the original purpose of responding to citizen inquiries, violating purpose limitation and lawfulness principles.
a75_case_summary: A Belgian politician used email addresses collected through his mayoral secretariat for electoral campaigning. The DPA found this violated purpose limitation and lawfulness principles under GDPR. The defendant also failed to implement proper security measures, resulting in a data breach when all recipients were visible. A €5000 fine was imposed considering the public official's role as aggravating.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; intentional/negligent character was mitigating (non-deliberate error); cooperation was aggravating (failed to share conclusions); other factors were aggravating (defendant's public role). Technical measures were aggravating due to inadequate security.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed legitimate interests for processing non-health data; DPA found legitimate interests valid for some purposes but invalid for staff training and CCTV storage; key reasoning was failure to demonstrate necessity and reasonable expectations
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found insurance company violated GDPR transparency and legal basis requirements in privacy statement. Company failed to demonstrate legitimate interests for staff training and CCTV storage purposes. DPA reduced fine from €50,000 to €30,000 considering some legitimate interests were valid and company made efforts to correct privacy statement.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity was aggravating; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; categories of data affected were aggravating; other factors included company's efforts to correct privacy statement as mitigating.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(b) GDPR (contract performance). The DPA found this legal basis valid as telephone recordings were necessary for proper contract execution and quality assurance between the parties.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2020 on data subject rights – right of access;Guidelines on transparency under Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA found a digital services company violated GDPR access rights by refusing to provide copies of recorded business calls, offering only on-site listening. The company claimed contract necessity for recordings but failed to facilitate proper access. The DPA upheld transparency violations regarding unclear privacy statements but rejected claims about unlawful processing basis.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included infringement seriousness and data protection measures failure. Mitigating factors included lack of intent, cooperation with authorities, and no previous infringements. Neutral factors included categories of personal data affected.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests for marketing; DPA found consent invalid due to lack of specificity and free will; legitimate interests invalid due to lack of balancing test
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 2/2019 on Article 6(1)(b) GDPR; Guidelines 05/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Vodafone España processed customer data for marketing without valid consent; DPA found multiple GDPR violations including invalid legal basis, lack of transparency, and security failures; Fine imposed for systematic consent issues and inadequate security measures; Company ordered to implement compliance measures within 3 months
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating factors included nature/gravity, intentional character, previous infringements, and categories of data; Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and actions to mitigate damage; Other mitigating factors considered included economic impact of COVID-19
authority_name_norm: Spanish Data Protection Agency

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed Article 6(1)(b) contract performance basis;DPA found email contained promotional content not necessary for contract execution;DPA also examined and rejected Article 6(1)(c),(e),(f) as legal bases
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data pursuant to Article 6(1)(b) GDPR;Guidelines for the Data Protection Officer
a75_case_summary: Belgian railway company NMBS sent promotional email to 3.6 million Hello Belgium Railpass applicants mixing commercial content with COVID-19 safety information;DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6(1) as email was not necessary for contract performance;Violations found of Articles 5(1)(a),(c),5(2),6(1),12(2),21(2),(3),(4);€10,000 fine imposed considering gravity and scale but one-off nature.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered gravity of infringements as aggravating;cooperation during investigation as mitigating;scale affecting almost third of Belgian population as aggravating;one-off nature limiting duration;fine imposed for deterrent effect given defendant's data-intensive business model.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent for cookies but DPA found consent invalid due to pre-ticked boxes and lack of specific consent. For other processing, no valid legal basis was demonstrated.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2016/679;Guidelines on consent under Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines on Data Protection Officers
a75_case_summary: Social housing company violated multiple GDPR principles including lawfulness, transparency, and accountability. Deficiencies included inadequate privacy policies, invalid consent for cookies, insufficient data protection officer arrangements, and unlawful processing of consumption data. The DPA found serious infringements but considered mitigating factors including defendant's willingness to adapt.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of infringements, negligent character, inadequate technical measures, categories of data affected, and non-compliance with prior orders. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority, and defendant's financial situation.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR for CCTV surveillance. The DPA found this invalid as the processing was not necessary for safeguarding those interests and the fundamental rights of data subjects outweighed the defendants' interests.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data through video equipment;EDPB Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25 Data Protection by Design and by Default
a75_case_summary: Private individuals installed CCTV cameras filming public roads and neighbors' properties. The DPA found violations of GDPR Article 6(1) (lawfulness) and Article 25(1) (data protection by design). The cameras excessively filmed public spaces and private properties without necessity. Defendants were reprimanded and fined €1500 jointly.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Duration was aggravating (months-long violations). Mitigating factors included defendants' remedial actions and non-commercial nature. The number of affected data subjects was aggravating. The fine was reduced from €2000 to €1500 based on defendants' financial response.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR but the DPA found it invalid as the interests did not prevail over data subjects' rights despite being legitimate; key reasoning included lack of reasonable expectation for commercial processing of publicly available professional data.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2019 on the criteria for the right to be forgotten in the search engine business pursuant to the GDPR;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The defendant operated a healthcare professional platform processing personal data of tens of thousands of professionals without valid legal basis; The DPA found legitimate interest invalid as commercial interests didn't outweigh data subjects' rights despite public nature of data; The defendant was ordered to cease processing and fined €10,000 for violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6(1)(f), and 12(2) with Article 17(1).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: severity was aggravating due to scale and duration; nature was aggravating as negligent; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; technical measures were aggravating; previous infringements were mitigating; categories of data were neutral; profit from infringement was aggravating.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests as legal basis for listing lawyers on referral sites. The DPA found this invalid as the processing was not necessary for the legitimate interests pursued and the interests of the data subjects outweighed the controller's interests.
a75_case_summary: The defendant operated lawyer referral websites listing lawyers without legal basis or consent. Information was often erroneous with falsely attributed testimonials. The DPA found violations of GDPR principles including lawfulness, fairness, transparency and information obligations. Processing lacked valid legal basis under Article 6.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the intentional character as mitigating, cooperation as mitigating, and technical measures as aggravating. The defendant's actions to mitigate damage were considered mitigating along with other mitigating factors.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed compliance with technical and organizational measures but failed to verify identities during SIM migration. The DPA found violations due to negligence in implementing proper security measures and failure to report the data breach.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines for the reporting of personal data breaches under Regulation 2016/679;Guideline on Examples regarding Data Breach Notification
a75_case_summary: A telecom provider failed to verify identity during SIM card migration, allowing a third party to gain access to a complainant's phone number for four days. The DPA found violations of Articles 5.1.f, 5.2, 24, 32, 33.1 and 33.5 GDPR due to insufficient technical measures and failure to report the breach. A fine of €20,000 was imposed considering the negligence and serious risk to privacy rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, intentional/negligent character as aggravating, and technical/organizational measures as aggravating. The fine was set at €20,000 considering the seriousness and need for deterrence.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found telecommunications company violated GDPR by responding to data subject's access request 14 months late. The company failed to facilitate access rights and initially claimed no DPO contact existed. The DPA imposed €100,000 fine considering the violation duration, company's negligence, and data processing as core activity.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to 14-month continuous violation. Negligence was aggravating as serious negligence was found. Mitigating actions were noted as the company eventually provided response. Other factors were neutral including no previous infringements and full cooperation.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for both transfer of membership file and marketing mailings. The DPA found legitimate interest valid for the file transfer in bankruptcy context but invalid for marketing due to transparency violations.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Opinion 06/2014 on the concept of legitimate interest of the controller
a75_case_summary: Football club acquired membership list during bankruptcy takeover and sent commercial mailings without proper transparency information. DPA found legitimate interest valid for file transfer but violated transparency principles and access rights. Fine imposed for information obligation breaches.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration and negligence were aggravating. Cooperation and mitigation measures were mitigating. Other factors were neutral.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Medical analysis laboratory processed health data through unsecured website using HTTP protocol instead of HTTPS; Inspectorate found insufficient security measures making data susceptible to man-in-the-middle attacks; DPA found violations of integrity/confidentiality principles and transparency obligations; €10,000 fine imposed.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for cookie processing; the DPA found the consent invalid due to non-compliant cookie banner implementation; the decision focuses on consent requirements under GDPR for cookie usage.
a75_case_summary: RTL Belgium's cookie banner was found non-compliant with GDPR consent requirements; the DPA invalidated consent as legal basis and found transparency obligations breached; corrective measures included reprimand and compliance order; a €50,000 fine was imposed considering aggravating and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; actions to mitigate damage and cooperation with authority were mitigating; technical measures were aggravating; other factors were not discussed.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for processing complainant's surname as project name; DPA found legitimate interest valid under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR as purpose was implementing court decisions, processing was necessary, and data subject could reasonably expect this use.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25 Data protection by design and by default;WP29 Guidelines for Data Protection Officers
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found bank violated GDPR by failing to implement diacritical marks in names despite technical capability, breaching accuracy principle and right to rectification. Bank also violated DPO independence requirements by combining DPO role with head of risk management departments. DPA imposed €75,000 fine for DPO conflict while dismissing other violations due to remedial actions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration and intentional/negligent character were aggravating; actions to mitigate damage, technical measures, previous infringements, and cooperation were mitigating. Fine reduced from €100,000 to €75,000 based on mitigating circumstances.
authority_name_norm: Data Protection Authority
